blocks.html: Just as 死了 (sǐle) can be used to intensify negative adjectives, 极了 (jíle) is a somewhat less common way to intensify both positive and negative adjectives. It is used in spoken, colloquial Chinese. 极 (jí) means "extreme" or "utmost."

This structure is technically a kind of degree complement and one of the few that you can use after the adjective and without adding a 得 (de). Remember to add the 了 (le), since it would be incorrect without it.
Some examples with a positive connotation:

children.english: This idea is perfect.
The taste is perfect!
His English is perfect.
The wedding was very lively.
There is no sound at all. It's extremely quiet.

blocks.html: Some examples with a negative connotation:

children.english: Yesterday's party was so boring!
He was so angry. We were all so scared.
I was super nervous the day I took the college entrance examination.
This incident made us all extremely embarrassed.
That boy is super annoying!

When you use 不怎么 (bù zěnme) before an adjective, it means "not very." You might use it to say something like "not very good."
When used together with an adjective, 不怎么 becomes similar to 不太, which means that the degree of the adjective is not very high.

Using this grammar structure is a way to indirectly or mildly state something. Instead of saying 他不聪明 (tā bù cōngming) you can say 他不怎么聪明 (tā bù zěnme cōngming), turning a very direct statement to a milder, more inoffensive comment.

children.english: It hasn't been very busy lately.
It's not very cold here in winter.
They don't seem to be very happy.
This student isn't very hard-working.
That restaurant isn't very clean.
This teacher isn't very professional.
Did you not sleep very well last night?
I'm not very into coffee.
He and his parents don't look very much alike.
He's been in the USA for more than one year, but he's not very homesick.

blocks.html: Remember that to make 不怎么 mean "not very" you need to use it with an adjective. Using it with a verb will give it the meaning of "not often."

One of the uses of 全 (quán) is to indicate the entirety of something. It could be used for something like a whole household, an entire country, the whole world, etc.

Simply put 全 in front of the noun you want to emphasize "the whole" of. You cannot use it with 的. Pay attention to the types of nouns you can use with 全, since it is usually paired up with 身 (body), 家 (family), 国 (country), 世界 (world), 天 (day) and the like.
The predicate part of the pattern can be a verb or an adjective.

children.english: Our entire family has been to Beijing.
The whole company doesn't like the new boss.
My whole body was sweaty after I finished exercising.
The whole school is on break.
This place is hot all year round.

blocks.html: Before a verb 全 can be omitted, but if it is used, the purpose is to emphasize the idea of "all" or "entire."

children.english: Everybody has arrived.
All of grandma's hair has turned white.
All of the food that my mother makes is tasty.
Have you finished all your homework?
Take them all.

blocks.html: When you negate 全都 with 不 or 没 after it, you're not just saying "not entirely," you're saying "none of it" or "not at all."

blocks.text: Subj. + 全都 + 不 / 没 + Predicate

children.english: None of them went.
None of us will be home this weekend.
Are none of you afraid?
None of these dishes is fully cooked.
I don't believe anything he says.

blocks.html: When you negate by putting 不 or 没 before 全都, you're only partially negating. In other words, you're communicating "not all."

blocks.text: Subj. + 不 / 没 + 全都 + Predicate

children.english: He has a point, but I don't agree with all of it.
The food was too much. We didn't finish eating it all.
I had too much homework yesterday. I didn't finish doing it all.
Not all of my family came to my wedding.
You spoke too fast. I didn't write down all of what you said.

One of the charming features of Chinese is reduplication (repeating, or doubling up) of certain words and characters, including adjectives. Reduplication can enhance the descriptive feeling of an adjective.

If an adjective is only one syllable (one character), then reduplicating it is a no-brainer. The only tricky part about this pattern is that not all adjectives can be reduplicated in natural speech. It's mostly for adjectives that describe the physical world: colors, sizes, shapes, and other physical descriptors.
In most Chinese textbooks and grammar books, this is known as the "AA" pattern. We'll be using this form more extensively below:
Note that this pattern is also identical to single-syllable reduplication of verbs.

children.english: Your face is red.
The baby's eyes are big.
The moon is round tonight.
Her father is tall and fat.
My little sister is thin and small.

blocks.html: If the adjective has more than one character, then you should repeat each character individually (rather than the whole word).  This is known as the "AABB" pattern.
In the structure below, the original two-character adjective (such as 高兴, 漂亮) is "AB," where the first character of the adjective is represented by "A," and the second by "B."

blocks.text: A  A  B  B  + 的 (+ Noun)

blocks.html: Not all two-syllable adjectives are used in AABB form, but here are some common examples of AB adjectives represented in AABB form.

children.english: happy
noisy, boisterous
pretty
comfortable
quiet and still

blocks.html: Not all adjectives can take AABB form.  Here are some examples of common adjectives that don't work in AABB form.

children.english: tasty
cheap
bothersome

blocks.html: When adjectives are used as adverbs to modify verbs, you can reduplicate the adjective using the AABB pattern.
Note: The "AABB" pattern for reduplication of two-syllable adjectives contrasts with the "ABAB" pattern for reduplication of two-syllable verbs.

children.english: We clearly saw him get in the car with a fat man.
I'd really like to comfortably lie on the couch and watch TV.
Your mother labored over this meal for two hours, and you aren't going to eat it?

blocks.html: If you use an adjective as a predicate, then you're basically using the adjective like a verb, and you reduplicate it as you would a verb, which means ABAB form. Using an adjective in this way is roughly equivalent to using 一下 after the (non-reduplicated) adjective.
To use a reduplicated adjective as a predicate, follow this structure:

In the pattern above there's no verb because when an adjective serves as the predicate, it does the job of a verb.  Notice also that there's no 的 after the ABAB, because 的 is used when modifying nouns.

children.english: My little sister's birthday is coming and I plan to throw her a birthday party and have a blast.
Come on, have a little wine and enjoy yourself.
Come over here and cool off.
I'd like to take a walk outside, get some quiet time.
Would you like to go get a massage and unwind?

正好 (zhènghǎo) can be used as an adjective or adverb to help express a coincidence, and it could be related to time, size, volume, quantity, degree, etc. In English we might say something similar like, “oh, this shirt you gave me just happens to be in my favorite color."
You can also use 正好 to mean "happen to be."

children.english: I'm just about to leave. I'll take out the trash.
You are here! I was just looking for you.
He happened to ask the question that I wanted to ask.
I happen to be interning here too.
You both happen to be single.
I'm going to meet with him tomorrow. I can just ask him about this matter.
We just happen to be going there. Let's go together.
He just happened to be leaving the house while I was knocking at the door.

blocks.html: You can also use 正好 by itself to mean "just right" or "just enough."

children.english: The size of these clothes is just right.
The temperature of the water is perfect, not too cold, not too hot.

Although 还 (hái) has many meanings, the basic meaning of "still" to indicate a continuing action is essential to mastery of the word.
Usage of 还在
Often the auxiliary verb 在 (zài) will appear with 还 (hái), as it is natural to talk about continuous actions that are still happening.

children.english: I am still thinking over this matter.
It's already noon and he's still sleeping?
Is she still mad?
How come you're still using that old cell phone?
You're still playing video games? Don't you have an exam tomorrow?

blocks.html: Usage of 还是
Here 还是 (háishì)--not literally "still is"--indicates what happened or will happen, despite the situation. The 是 (shì) here doesn't have a clear meaning here independent of 还 (hái).

blocks.text: ⋯⋯ ，(但是 / 可是 +) Subj. + 还是 + [Verb Phrase]

children.english: I told him not to buy it, but he still bought it.
He didn't want to get divorced, but in the end he still ended up getting divorced.
His parents didn't agree to it, but he still went.
The doctor told her to stop drinking, but she still drinks.
The teacher is sick, but she still come to class.

blocks.html: When you put 不 or 没 after 还 (hái) in a question sentence, it can be used to emphasize the idea of what should be happening in a more idiomatic way.

blocks.text: Subj. + 还 + 不 / 没 + [Verb Phrase]

children.english: We've been waiting for half an hour, but the teacher still hasn't arrived.
The movie has started already, and you still haven't left the house?

children.explanation: implying the listener should get married now
children.english: You're in your forties, and you still don't want to get married?
I've explained it so many times, and you still don't get it?

children.explanation: implying the listener shouldn't be so upset
children.english: I treat you so well, but you're still not happy?

As an adverb, 就 (jiù) can be placed before the predicate to add emphasis. It often has an intense or provocative feel to it, similar to "just." In English we might say, "it's just not right!" This emphasis very often appears as 就是 in Chinese.

children.english: That guy is her new boyfriend.
He's just the person that you're looking for.
We're his family.
A moron is precisely what you are!
That con man is him!

blocks.html: 就是 can be used to intensify the predicate to mean "only (because of) that and nothing else." In this case, 是 can't be omitted. In many cases, you could also add in an 因为, but it's not required.

children.english: He didn't travel only because he doesn't want to spend the money.
You're not entering the competition just because you're afraid of losing?
He said this only because he doesn't like me.
She asked so many questions only because she's worried about you.
She's just pretty; she doesn't have any other strengths.

blocks.html: In the examples above, 就 pairs exclusively with the verb 是. But 就 can also come before other verbs, with similar emphatic effect. In these cases, it's also OK to use 就是 before the other verbs as well.

children.english: I just want to go!
I just like him.
I'm just not going to tell you.
My parents simply won't let me go alone.
The student just wouldn't listen to his teacher.

blocks.html: As you may have noticed, many of these uses of 就 or 就是 carry a flippant, stubborn tone, referred to as 任性 (rènxìng) in Chinese.

You already know that 不 (bù) and 没 (méi) can be used for negation. But you can also use the word 又 (yòu) to emphasize negation, giving your negative sentence a little kick!

In this structure, 又 is used to emphasize that something "didn't happen," "is not" the case, or "will not happen." It's most often used with 不 and 没. This grammar structure is often used in an accusatory context, and when used with other expressions like 干吗 (gànmá) can show annoyance.

children.english: Why ask me? I definitely don't know.
These dishes haven't gone bad. Why would you throw them away?
Don't be mad.It really wasn't on purpose.
It's not hot today. Why turn on the air conditioner?
You don't work tomorrow. Why get up so early?
You're not busy now. Come and help me.
I haven't eaten it. How would I know if it is tasty or not?
The child didn't do anything wrong. Why are you spanking him?
It's not raining. Why are you bringing the umbrella?
It's none of your business. Why all the questions?

title: Expressing "about to" with "jiuyao"
pattern: 还有 + Time Period + 就要 + Verb Phrase + 了

blocks.html: 就要 (jiùyào) is similar to 快要 (kuàiyào), meaning "about to." They are interchangeable in some cases. But there is a major difference that you need to take a good look at.

children.english: It's about to rain.
They are about to get married.
I'm about to go abroad.
The baby is about to be one year old.
The class is almost over. Are there any other questions?

blocks.html: In this case, 就要 can be replaced by 快要 or 快.

快要 (kuài yào) is generally "about to" [happen], but 就要 (jiù yào) could be used to mark a more specific time. 要 (yào) here can be omitted. For this one, you wouldn't normally use "about to" for this English translation, but the feeling is nevertheless that the impending event is coming up fast. This use of 就 (jiù) overlaps with its usage indicating earliness.

blocks.text: 还有 + Time (+ Subj.) + 就 (要) + Verb + 了

children.english: I get off work in 10 minutes.
We're just two weeks away from the exam date.
It will be Chinese New Year in another month.
The plane takes off in half an hour.
I go on vacation in 5 days.

While 又 (yòu) is used for "again" in the past, 再 (zài) is used for "again" in the future. That is, 再 is used when something has happened once and it will happen again.

children.english: We'll come again next year.
Try it again.
Can you please say it again?
I want to read this book again.
You should review it again.

blocks.html: In fact, this structure is present in one of the most common Chinese phrases: "再见!" In this case, it literally means "see you again."
The English word "another" is often avoided altogether by using 再.
In this case, the object includes a quantity phrase.

children.english: Eat some more.
Let's order some more dishes.
Waiter, two more bottles of beer, please.
Give me another three days.
Can I take two more?

blocks.html: Here 再 is similar to the English "for a while longer" or "keep [going/doing]."

children.english: Keep looking.
Keep asking.
Don't worry. Keep thinking.

blocks.html: You can also add 一会儿 after the verb to mean "keep doing something a little longer."

children.english: Keep talking for a little bit.
Wait a little longer.

blocks.html: You can use either the "Verb + Verb" pattern or the 一会儿 pattern with 再, but don't use them together.

blocks.html: Whenever you want to express something that has happened again, as in, "oops, I did it again!" in Chinese, you generally want to use 又 (yòu). (You'll want to use 再 (zài) for "again" in the future.)
Normally, 又 is used to express an action that has already happened again for (at least) the second time. It doesn't have to be in quick succession; it happened before, and now it's happened again.

children.english: It rained again!
You're late again.
The baby is crying again.
I forgot again.
He didn't come to class again.
You're not paying again?
You are not going to participate again?
Sorry, I forgot to bring the book again.

blocks.html: Colloquial Saying 又来了

又来了 fits the above pattern, but is also a little tricky because it expresses something that is still ongoing, and has already started as the speaker is speaking. Literally it means "here it comes again," but it's more accurate to translate it as "there it is again," or "there [he] goes again." It indicates that the speaker is a bit annoyed that it happened again.

When it becomes clear that something is about to happen again, you can also use 又. It's almost as if it has already happened in your mind. In these cases, it's quite common for 又 to be immediately followed by 是 (shì), 要 (yào), 可以 (kěyǐ), or 能 (néng), and you'll notice that there's often a 了, indicating that something is about to happen.

children.english: We've got to work overtime again today!
The boss is going to treat us. We can have a big meal again!
It's almost Chinese New Year. We can get our red packets [of money] again!

So it was you all along!

blocks.html: 一下子 (yīxiàzi) can be used as an adverb, meaning "all at once." Because it inherently encompasses a sense of "completion," it's typically going to be followed by a 了 (le) later in the sentence.

一下子 (yīxiàzi) is a very informal expression to describe how fast things happened. It usually touches upon sudden or severe changes in a very short amount of time. Although 一下子 (yīxiàzi) is already quite informal, in colloquial Chinese 一下 (yīxià) can also be used to express the same thing.

blocks.text: Subj. + 一下子 + Predicate + 了

children.english: The weather suddenly got cold.
He ate three bowls of rice all at once.
As she went down the stairs, she suddenly fell.
She burst into tears when we were talking.
Last month, she lost a lot of weight all at once.

blocks.html: 一下子 (yīxiàzi), followed with 就 (jiù), usually implies that things happened very quickly, naturally, and easily. Again, 一下 (yīxià) can also be used instead of 一下子 (yīxiàzi).

blocks.text: Subj. + 一下子 + 就 + Predicate + 了

children.english: Everyone became silent after the teacher came in.
After hearing him out, I understood everything all at once.
He is the tallest. I spotted him right away.
He became very famous soon after that movie came out.
It all came back to me when I saw that picture.

To say that something bad almost happened (but didn't), you can add the word 差点 (chàdiǎn) before the verb. You will also hear 差点儿 (chàdiǎnr) in northern China. There is no difference in meaning between 差点 and 差点儿.

It might help to understand the literal meaning of the structure. The word 差 has a lot of meanings. In this case, it means "to lack," or "to be short." So in Chinese, the way to say "almost" is to say, "lacking that little bit." If that "little bit" hadn't been lacking, it would have happened. But it was lacking, so it didn't happen; it almost happened. Just remember: the fact of what really happened is always NOT the verb phrase after 差点(儿).
Note that the "Predicate" part of the structure is usually something bad or something you don't wish for, and that it didn't happen.
You can put 了 at the end of the sentence for emphasis. In this case, 就 is often used and it's optional.

blocks.text: Subj. + 差点 (+就) + Predicate + 了

blocks.html: The predicate part of the pattern can be a verb or an adjective.

children.explanation: The car didn't hit me.
children.english: The car almost hit me.

children.explanation: We didn't believe him.
children.english: We almost believed him.

children.explanation: They didn't start fighting.
children.english: They almost started a fight.

children.explanation: I didn't forget.
children.english: I almost forgot.

children.explanation: I wasn't late.
children.english: I was almost late today.

children.explanation: She didn't go crazy.
children.english: She almost went crazy.

children.explanation: He didn't die.
children.english: He almost died.

children.explanation: It wasn't burned.
children.english: The food was almost burned.

children.explanation: The team didn't lose.
children.english: Our team almost lost.

children.explanation: I didn't actually do it.
children.english: I almost hit him.

都⋯⋯了 (dōu... le) is a pattern used to express that something has already happened, similar to 已经 (yǐjīng)⋯⋯了. However, 都⋯⋯了 is used more emphatically, implying that the speaker holds some sort of attitude in relation to the event and is not merely objectively stating the facts, as with 已经⋯⋯了. The two options can actually also be combined in the pattern 都已经⋯⋯了. Here the meaning is the same as 都⋯⋯了.
When 都⋯⋯了 (dōu... le) is used at the beginning of a sentence, it will usually be followed with 还 (hái) or 还在 (hái zài). This implies that the other party should stop some kind of action.

children.english: It's already nine o'clock. Get out of bed!
It's already 12 o'clock. Aren't you going to bed?
It's already the 21st century and you still think this way?
It's already been an hour, and he's still in the bathroom.
It's been a week and it's still raining.

blocks.html: The predicate part of the pattern can be a verb or an adjective.

children.english: The food is cold already. Let's eat.
The milk's gone bad. Throw it out.
I've said it three times already. Leave me alone!
You've seen this movie already. Let's watch something else.
He already apologized. Stop being so mad at him.

Although perhaps more often used in the negative to mean "never," 从来 (cónglái) can be used with 都 (dōu) to mean "always" or "have always (done)."

Without the negative adverbs 不 and 没, 从来 takes on the meaning of "always." (Literally, 从来 means something like "from the beginning," although no one is really thinking that phrase when they use it.) When used in the positive, though, it is customary to put the adverb 都 after 从来.

blocks.text: Subj. + 从来 + 都 (是) + Predicate

blocks.html: The predicate part of the pattern can be a verb or an adjective. It's also quite common to follow 从来都 with an additional 是 for emphasis.

children.english: He's always like this.
She's always gone to bed so late.
He's always spoken very loudly.
Students in our school can only wear school uniforms.
Success always depends on working hard by oneself.
He always wins when we play chess.
She always buys brand-name clothes when she goes shopping.
I've always lived alone; I'm used to it already.

结果 (jiéguǒ) can be used as a conjunction or adverb, meaning "as a result" or "consequently." It normally starts the second half of a sentence and can also introduce an unexpected or undesirable result.

children.english: She didn't dress warmly enough, and as a result, she caught a cold.
I was too nervous. As a result, I misspoke a lot.
He drove too fast. As a result, he hit someone.
He didn't review well. As a result, he didn't do well in the exam.
He's always late for work. As a result, his boss fired him.

blocks.html: Sometimes there is no cause-effect relationship between what comes before and after 结果 (no logical connection). In these sentences, the second half of the sentence usually emphasizes that what actually happened was unexpected or undesired.

children.english: I went to the airport to pick him up. But in the end, I didn't find him there.
I made a bet with a friend. I lost in the end.
I went to have a drink with my friends yesterday. I ended up getting drunk.
He took a lot of pills. None of them worked in the end.
I ordered a burger. The waiter gave me a chicken sandwich instead.

blocks.html: Saying how long you have not done something is not difficult, but the word order is different from the regular pattern for expressing duration. If there's a consistent keyword in this pattern, it's going to be 没 (méi), since it almost always plays a role.
Remember, this pattern differs from both simple pattern for expressing duration and the pattern for ongoing duration.

blocks.text: Subj. + (已经 +) Duration + 没 + Verb + 了

blocks.html: So now the duration comes right after the subject and 了 is at the end of the sentence. The verb has to be negated with 没, as the action hasn't happened.
Note that 已经 can be omitted.

children.english: They haven't eating anything for two days already.
We haven't seen each other for ten years already.
He has already gone a whole week without showering.
How long has it been since you last shaved?
It's been half a month since she's left the house.
How long has it been since you returned home?
How long has it been since your last vacation?
Just buy it. It's been more than one year since you last bought new clothes.
It seems like it's been a long time since you were this happy.

blocks.html: In English, we may say something like, "I haven't eaten since 9:00 this morning" or "I haven't been to China since the year 2000." Note that the Chinese do not tend to say somebody hasn't done something since a certain point in time. Instead, you should either express it as a duration of time that one hasn't done something (as in the above examples), or you can say "the last time somebody did something was [a certain point in time]."

children.english: It's been 10 years since I came to China last.
The last time I came to China was 2010.

When some action is mutual, you can use the word 互相 (hùxiāng). The word "mutual" feels formal in English, but in Chinese, even everyday phrases such as "learn from each other" use the word 互相, which expresses this "each other" aspect.
Usually 互相 (hùxiāng) is used with two-syllable words, and for one-syllable words, some other information will be added after the verb to make it sound more natural (see below for examples of this.)

children.english: Help each other
Know each other
Hurt each other
Respect each other
Support each other
Encourage each other
Influence each other
Use each other

blocks.html: Don't use 互相 (hùxiāng) with single-syllable verbs. If you really have to use 互相, you can make the verb longer by adding extra information after it.

children.english: look at each other
glanced at each other

blocks.html: Note that for some verbs which are inherently "mutual," the use of 互相 (hùxiāng) is redundant and unnecessary. So the following phrases are not wrong, but a little strange.

children.english: hug each other
communicate with each other

title: Expressing earliness with "jiu"
pattern: Subj. + Time + 就 + Verb + 了

blocks.html: Just as 才 (cái) can express lateness, 就 (jiù) can be used to indicate that something happened earlier or sooner than expected. It can also be used in the near future to indicate something will happen very soon.
When something happens "right away," you're talking about "very soon" in the future.

children.english: I'll be there in a second.
The rice will be ready in 20 minutes.
Are you leaving the house right now?
They will be here in a few minutes.
The boss will be back tomorrow.

blocks.html: Note that it can sometimes be hard to translate the feeling of "soonness" into English, but in every one of these examples, the time given in the sentences feels "soon" to the speaker.
This use of 就 might be translated "as early as," but usually the earliness is not specifically marked in English.

blocks.text: Subj. + [Point in Time] + 就 + Verb + 了

children.english: We have class at nine, but he came in at eight.
The plane takes off at ten o'clock, but he arrived at the airport at six.
I went to bed at eight thirty last night.
She graduated from college when she was only 18 years old.

blocks.html: Not only can 就 emphasize a "point in time," but it can also emphasize a "time period," indicating that something happened very quickly.

blocks.text: Subj. + Time Period + 就 + Verb + 了

children.english: It only took you just one night to finish reading it?
It only took him ten minutes to finish doing it.

blocks.html: From the example sentences it is clear that 了 naturally occurs with a verb used after 就. This is because verbs following 就 generally have the feeling of being completed.
Colloquial Saying 早就
早就 means "long ago," and is usually used to express a kind of impatience or surprise on the part of the speaker. It comes before the verb.

children.english: I knew that long ago!
She got married a long time ago.
They broke up a long time ago.
We graduated a long time ago!
I told you a long time ago that he's not a good guy.

blocks.html: In Chinese the word for "enough" is 够 (gòu). It also combines with other words and most often comes before verbs and adjectives, but there are a limited number of verbs that it can follow as well.
The 了 is not strictly required, but it adds a sense of emphasis.
In these examples, 够 (gòu) comes before verbs. You'll notice that who is doing the verb to what is normally just understood in context.

children.english: We bought a lot of food. It's enough for us to eat.
Is this paper enough for us to use?
Don't worry. I've brought enough money to spend.

blocks.html: When it comes before an adjective, 了 is needed at the end of the sentence.

children.english: I've been good enough to you.
Stop complaining. You've been lucky enough.

blocks.html: In the negative form, you're not going to need a 了 (le).

blocks.text: Subj. + 不 + 够 + Adj. / Verb

blocks.html: Note that 了 can't be used when it's negated.

children.english: He thinks his girlfriend is not pretty enough.
You didn't speak clearly enough.
This food is not enough for us to eat. Let's order a few more dishes.
It's too cramped here. There's not enough room to sit.
Your bag is too small. There's definitely not enough room to hold this stuff.

blocks.html: Translations feel looser here, as the Chinese frequently omits the details about what's not enough for what. The verb and the context makes it clear enough.
Literally, 够了 means "it's enough." When the speaker is getting sick of doing something or feeling fed up, 够了 can be applied after a limited number of verbs.

children.english: I've had enough!
We eat take-out every day. We're sick of eating it.
Are you done playing?

终于 (zhōngyú) expresses that something has finally happened after a long wait. Usually the speaker is looking forward to what is happening at long last, and thus, 终于 (zhōngyú) typically carries a sense of joy or relief.

Unlike the English word "finally," 终于 (zhōngyú) can never be used alone. It also can’t be put in front of the subject or at the end of the sentence. 终于 (zhōngyú) needs to be used with 了 to express that the action is completed.
The predicate part of the pattern can be a verb or an adjective.

children.english: You've finally arrived!
We're finally meeting each other!
You've finally understood.
I've finally finished my homework!
The plane is finally taking off!
You've finally decided.
Dinner is finally ready. I'm starving.
This dream has finally come true!
We'd been looking for more than two hours, and we finally found that shop.
The problems are finally solved. We should celebrate!

blocks.html: One of the ways to use 还是 (háishì) is to have it mean "you had better," after having compared two options. Usually there's even a bit of deliberation before the speaker announces what "it would be better" to do, using 还是.

还是 as an adverb can express "had better" or "it would be better to." The idea is that the speaker has given the matter some thought, and after considering it, has finally come to a decision. The announcement of this decision will frequently include 还是, and it usually comes before a verb or a subject.
吧 is often placed after this structure, as it's a suggestion.

children.english: We'd better go tomorrow.
We'd better let her come in.
You'd better leave now.
We'd better help him.
It's too late. We'd better go home now.
It's too dirty here; we'd better leave.
We're running late. Let's take a taxi.

blocks.html: When the part after 还是 is a negative verb phrase, it's OK to drop the 吧 at the end.

children.english: It's too expensive. You'd better not buy it.
She doesn't want to say. We'd better not ask again.
He will definitely not agree to it. We'd better not say anything to him.

The predicate part of the pattern can be a verb or an adjective.

children.english: You'd better get some rest first.
It would be best for you to give him a call and ask.
It's not easy to find that place. We'd better search for it on Baidu Maps.
It's pretty cold outside. Best to wear some more layers.
This is an important event. We'd better wear something more formal.

children.english: You'd better not go.
It's best not to say something like this.
It's best not to eat so much for dinner.
It's raining so heavily. It's best not to leave the house.

这样 (zhèyàng) is used at the beginning of a phrase to express "this way" or "in this way."

children.english: Doing it this way is not right.
It's not polite to say this.
If you walk over this way, it's closer.
Do you guys really think so?

blocks.html: This use of 这样 corresponds to "in this way," which is another way of expressing "so that" or "thus."
You will often see 会 or 才 following 这样 to indicate "only in this way can or will something happen."

children.english: You need to encourage your students more. This will help them become more confident.
Parents should spend more time with their children. This will make the children happier.
You need to speak more. Only in this way will you become more and more fluent.
Let him do it by himself. This is the only way he will learn.

blocks.html: Colloquial Saying 这样的话

This use of 这样 corresponds to "this way," as in "if we do it this way." Adding 的话 gives the pattern more of a hypothetical "if" flavor. To make the "if" even more explicit, you can even add 如果是 before 这样的话.

children.english: If this is the case, do you still want to go?
If this is the case, we're in for a heap of trouble.
I will stay at my American friend's house when I go to visit the US. This way my family won't worry about me so much.

To express that something happened later than expected, you can use 才 (cái). In English, this might be expressed with "as late as" or "not until." This form is often used with a time of some sort, like a specific time of day, age, etc. This pattern is essentially the opposite of using 就 (jiù) to express earliness.

children.english: I didn't arrive at home until eleven o'clock last night.
He didn't go to college until he was 25.
She didn't get married until she was forty.
My daughter didn't go to bed until 12 o'clock yesterday. Too much homework.
You start work at nine o'clock, but don't get up until 8:30?
The airplane just took off. It was delayed for two hours.
The movie began at 7:30, but we didn't arrive until eight because of traffic.

blocks.html: You can use 才 alone with the verb to indicate the lateness when the context is clear:

children.english: How come you are eating dinner now? It's 10 pm.
How come you came here so late? We've waited for more than half an hour.

blocks.html: Note that verbs following 才 should not take 了.

title: Expressing "one by one" with "yi"
pattern: 一 + Measure Word + 一 + Measure Word

blocks.html: The expression "one by one" is also simple in Chinese. It unsurprisingly features the word 一 (yī), but you don't even need the word "by." However, the pattern gets complicated somewhat by the concept of measure words.

The most obvious way to express "one by one" is 一个一个 (yī gè yī gè), and this expression is, in fact, quite common, especially when referring to people doing things "one by one." But other measure words can be used in the same pattern instead of 个.

blocks.text: 一 + Measure Word + 一 + Measure Word (+ Noun)

blocks.html: 个 is the most likely candidate for the "Measure Word" slot here.

children.english: Don't argue. Speak one by one.
Don't worry, do it little by little.
Please inspect room by room.
Don't carry so much. Carry them one at a time.

blocks.html: Aside from just meaning "one by one," when 一 (yī) is used with a measure word that is a unit of time like "day" or "year," the meaning changes to "little by little" ("day by day," "year by year") or "gradually."

blocks.text: 一 + Time Unit + 一 + Time Unit (+ Noun)

children.english: The baby is growing up day by day.
Year by year, mom and dad are growing old.

blocks.html: When a measure word phrase like "one time" is repeated, the meaning also changes. When using a verb measure word like 次 (cì) or 遍 (biàn), using this pattern can indicate how the action is performed or indicate repetition of the the action.

blocks.text: 一 + [Measure Word] (+ 又) + 一 + [Measure Word]

blocks.html: If the speaker wants to emphasize that the action has been repeated many times, 又 (yòu) can add emphasis.

children.english: I asked him again and again, but he just wouldn't say anything.
I explained it to him again and again, but he still won't listen.
Why do you listen to this song over and over again?
They keep making the same mistake over and over again, and it's giving their manager a headache.

blocks.html: 就 (jiù) is often translated simply as "just" or "only," but there are some nuances to how it is used.

就 can also be used to express one person or thing, similar to how we say in English "just one person" or "just one left." It is often paired with 一个 or similar in order to emphasize the small quantity.
The predicate part of the pattern can be a verb or an adjective.

children.english: I'm the only person that knows about this.
We all forgot. Only he still remembers it.
Everyone finished work and left. Only the boss hasn't left.
The other dishes are great. Just these two dishes are a little salty.
Do you think everyone else is an idiot? That only you are smart?

blocks.html: In this case, the 就 comes before the verb, and what's being emphasized as "small quantity" comes after the verb, either as an object or some other kind of small quantity.
In this structure, the verb phrase is going to include some kind of measure word.

children.english: I've only been there once.
I only had a piece of bread for breakfast.
You ordered only two dishes?
We only know a little about his business.
She has worked at our company for only two months.

blocks.html: In this case, 就 means "only have," similar in meaning to 只有. (In these cases, however, 就有 would not be correct. Just use 就.)

children.english: Does this place only have one bathroom?
Does your family only have one child?
I only have one brother.
He only has one friend in Shanghai.
There are only three employees in our company.

The word 再 (zài) actually has a lot of uses, beyond just "again," and in this pattern it means something like "and then." 先⋯⋯，再⋯⋯ (xiān..., zài...) is a pattern used for sequencing events, much like "first..., then..." in English. This pattern can also include 然后 (ránhòu), meaning "and after that."
In the pattern below, 先 means "first" and 再 has a meaning of "then" or "and then."

children.english: Wash your hands first, and then eat.
I prefer to take a bath first and then go to bed.
Please buy a ticket first and then enter.
You need to do your homework first, and then watch TV.
I want to find a job first, and then move.

blocks.html: Colloquial Usage with 再说
You may have learned that 再说 can mean "in addition." Well, the usage of 再 here is a more literal combination of 再说, fitting into the 先⋯⋯再⋯⋯ pattern.

So in this usage, 再说 doesn't really mean "in addition."  Rather, it most literally means, "and then we'll talk."  In other words, "let's just do this now," and then after we see the result, we can talk some more about next steps. There's a "let's see how this goes first" feeling to the expression.
Note that in the pattern below, the sentence normally ends with 再说.
The 再说 part in the following sentences can be a little tricky to translate into English.

children.english: Let's eat first, then we'll talk.
Let's rest a little first, then we'll see.
Finish reading first, and then we'll see.
I'm going to ask the boss first before doing anything else.
You guys discuss a little first, then we'll figure out what to do next.

blocks.html: "and then..." with 接着

When describing a series of actions, steps, or consecutive events, your Chinese will sound more natural if you can diversify your conjunctions. 然后 (ránhòu) is most commonly used, a conjunction which means "and then." Alternatively, you can use 接着 (jīezhe), as a conjunction that means "next," or "afterwards."
A longer example to help you understand how they can all work together:

You can also use 老 instead of 老是. The predicate part of the pattern can be a verb or an adjective.

In  English, the words "that" and "so" are often used to emphasize the degree of an adjective (ex. "he is so tall" or "the food is so good"). In Chinese, 那么 (nàme) and 这么 (zhème) serve the same function.
All you have to do to use this grammar structure is put the 那么 or 这么 in front of the adjective.

blocks.text: Subj. + 那么 / 这么 + Adj.

blocks.html: You could think of 这么 as "this" or "so," and 那么 as "that" or "so."

blocks.html: When to use which one

You might be thinking that since 这 ("this") and 那 ("that") have totally different meanings, how could they be used in an essentially interchangeable way? Well, there are some differences. 这么 is used when the subject is close by (either in space or in time), when you would say "this" or 这个. On the other hand, if the subject is far away (or in the past), you would likely use 那么.

blocks.html: 什么的 (shénme de) is an informal way to express "and so on," and is used to end a list of items when it is obvious to the listener what class of things the speaker is talking about. 什么的 can also be used after a single item if it is obvious enough what might follow.

children.english: My grandma doesn't eat meat. She only eats vegetables, tofu, and so on.
Having a dog is too much trouble. You need to feed it, give it a bath, play with it, and so on.
Math, physics, chemistry, and so on. I'm not interested in any of them.

When we meet, we just eat a meal, chat, and so on.

Running, swimming, basketball, and so on. He likes all these sports.

When you live alone, laundry, cooking, and so on all need to be done yourself.
Televisions, washing machines, and so on. My father can fix all those.

blocks.html: It can be a little impolite to use 什么的 after a list of peoples names, in which case 等 can be used in place of 什么的. When referring to a list of friends in informal contexts there is no problem using 什么的.

blocks.html: 等等 (děng děng) or simply 等 (děng), is just like saying “and so on” or “etc.” in English, but it's just a bit more formal.  Both are placed after listing a series of items (generally with a list that exceeds two items).

The basic structure is easy. Just make a list of things and add 等 (děng) or 等等 (děng děng) to the end of the list. It's the same as in English when we use "etc." at the end of a list, except in Chinese you don't put a final comma before the 等 or 等等.

title: Using "lai" to connect two verb phrases
pattern: 通过 / 用 + Method + 来 + Verb Phrase

blocks.html: The word 来 (lái) can be used to connect two verb phrases, relating the actions to each other. It can be translated as "in order to" or "so that," and it can help in explaining reasoning.

Connecting two verb phrases is very straightforward. All you need to do is place 来 in between them. This has the meaning of doing the first verb to achieve the second verb and is often used with words expressing a way or a method, e.g. 通过 (tōngguò) or 用 (yòng).

The words "before" and "after" can be expressed using 之前 (zhīqián) and 之后 (zhīhòu). They are very similar to 以前 (yǐqián) and 以后 (yǐhòu), but are slightly more formal.
Used at the End of a Phrase
blocks.text: Used at the End of a Phrase

blocks.html: In this pattern, 之前 and 之后 come at the start of a sentence, right after mention of some kind of event or thing that happened.

children.english: Before I came to China, my Chinese was really mediocre.
Give me a call after you get off work.
What about going to the movies after eating dinner?

She needs to go to piano lessons every day after school.

blocks.html: Used as a Time Word
In this pattern, 之前 and 之后 usually come at the start of a phrase, in the middle of a sentence.

children.english: He finished university in England. Afterwards, he returned to Shanghai.
She's been a Chinese teacher for more than four years. She used to be an English teacher.
The boss just came back. He was on vacation before.
None of us knew. He didn't say anything before.
I'm going to eat now. After that I will go meet a client.

blocks.html: One difference between the two pairs is that 之前/之后 feel more formal simply because they contain 之, which is a word common in classical Chinese. Both words are still used in everyday spoken Chinese, however.

blocks.html: You can express "ever since" in Chinese using 以来 (yǐlái) after a time in the past. Just the word 来 (lái) can also play a similar role.
Pattern with 以来

To express "ever since," all one needs to do is put 以来 after a specific event or time. It expresses what has happened since the stated event until the time that the speaker talks (in other words, referring to a certain continuous time period leading up to the present).
This grammar pattern is usually used to start a statement.

Although we won't go into detail here, note that when using 以来 in a more formal or written context, you can add 自, 从, or 自从 (or other similar words) before the time or event to make it into a "sandwich pattern."

children.english: It hasn't rained since August of this year.
Since we got married we haven't had a fight.
Since starting college, he's changed a lot.
He hasn't returned home since his father passed away.
Since I started studying Chinese, I've made a lot of Chinese friends.

blocks.html: Pattern with 来

Using 来 to mean "ever since" is basically the same as 以来. However, there is one key difference: you can only use 来 after a length of time, rather than a specific date. In other words, it needs to be used with a certain number of years, months, days, hours, etc. In English, this would be like saying "Ever since three days ago, I've had a constant headache." It doesn't have to be a specific number either; it could be "a few" (几).
This form cannot be used with 自, 从, or 自从 (or other similar words).

children.english: For the past decade, housing prices have been continuously going up.
Our company's income has been steadily increasing over the past few years.
I've learned a lot from my internship during the last few months.
She hasn't missed home at all since she went abroad a few month ago.
Since getting divorced these past few years, he's never visited his child.
I've been missing her every day these past three months.

blocks.html: 分之 (fēn zhī) is used to express fractions in Chinese. When expressing a fraction, the denominator is always said before the numerator. This pattern is also the way percentages are expressed in Chinese.

So "½" is read 二分之一 (èr fēn zhī yī), literally "1 of 2 portions." Note the order: it's NOT 一分之二 (yī fēn zhī èr). So "¾" is 四分之三 (sì fēn zhī sān), and "⅚" is 六分之五 (liù fēn zhī wǔ). To say a percentage, for example, 50 percent, you would say 百分之五十 (bǎi fēn zhī wǔshí), which is literally the same as how you would pronounce the equivalent fraction "50 hundredths."

Remember that the denominator is the bottom number in a fraction, but it comes first in spoken Chinese. Knowing that this order actually totally fits the overall "big to small" Chinese cultural pattern might help you to remember.

children.english: My phone only has 5% power left.
This document is two-thirds downloaded.
Three fifths of this article has been copied from others.
About one third of Americans have passports.
Three fourths of the teachers at our school are male teachers.

blocks.html: This structure is what you'll often see in news stories that use statistics. The word 占 (zhàn) is a bit more formal, and means something like "comprises" or "makes up" or "accounts for."

More advanced students, however, will note that 吗 has some more complicated structures that do involve combining 吗 with question words in order to ask very specific types of confirming questions.

The particle 着 (zhe) is one way of indicating the continuous aspect in Mandarin Chinese (another common way is using the adverb 在 in front of verbs). You may have heard that the Chinese particle 着 added onto the end of verbs is similar to the use of -ing in English. This isn't particularly helpful, however, because the use of 着 in Chinese is not nearly so commonly used, and can also be quite idiomatic.
The main idea here is that the action won't just happen and stop immediately; it will continue for a while.
This basic pattern is often used with commands involving certain verbs where the action persists for a while.

children.english: I'll read, and you listen.
We will do it, and you all watch.
Sit for a while. I'll be right back.
I'll go out for a second, and you watch the luggage for me.

blocks.html: Used for Manner or State in which an Action is Performed
blocks.text: Used for Manner or State in which an Action is Performed

blocks.html: This pattern is used when you want to use one verb to describe how another action is performed.
Note that the first verb (followed by 着) describes the state; the second verb is the action verb. In this case, the "-ing" translation can be useful for the state.

children.explanation: "standing + eat = eating while standing"
children.english: She likes to eat standing up.

children.explanation: "smiling + say = saying "I'm sorry" while smiling
children.english: Smiling, he said, "I'm sorry."

children.explanation: "hugging + cry = crying while hugging
children.english: Hugging his daddy, the child started to cry.

blocks.html: Note: If you want to make a sentence where both verbs are action verbs (neither is truly a state), then you don't want this pattern; you want 一边⋯⋯，一边⋯⋯ (yībiān..., yībiān...).
While it's true that the "full progressive pattern" can make use of 着, this is not a pattern you're going to want to use all the time.
The verbs most commonly used with 着 are the ones below:
• 开 (kāi) alone can mean "to open" or "to turn on." Adding 着 allows one to express that something "is open" or "is on."
• 关 (guān) alone can mean "to close" or "to turn off." Adding 着 allows one to express that something "is closed" or "is off."
• 穿 (chuān) alone means "to wear." Adding 着 allows one to express that one "is wearing" something (on one's person).
• 戴 (dài) alone means "to wear" (an accessory). Adding 着 allows one to express that one "is wearing" a hat, jewelry, or accessory (on one's person).
• 躺 (tǎng) alone means "to lie on one's back." Adding 着 allows one to express that someone "is lying down."

children.explanation: "Being open" is not an action, so don't use 在.)
"Be wearing" is a state, so using 着 is natural.)

children.explanation: "Be wearing" is not an action, so don't use 在.)
"Lying down" is a state, so using 着 is natural.)
children.english: It's most comfortable just lying down.

children.explanation: "Lying here" is not strictly an action, so don't use 在.)

When 吧 (ba) is used twice in a sentence, it is used to list two options that the speaker is debating. It gives the sentence an indecisive feel, as though the speaker doesn't know which one to choose. This construction often has a negative connotation, since the options usually are not ideal.
If this structure doesn't seem clear to you, the examples will help.

If we go early, we'll have to wait. If we go later, there will be bad traffic.
If I wear a little more, it will be hot. If I wear a little less, it will be cold.
I need to give a red envelope if I go early. If I don't go, he will lose face.
If I don't tell him, he will still do it wrong next time. If I do tell him, he will get upset.

blocks.html: The particle 的 (de) is most often a structural particle, but it can also be a sentence-final particle which indicates that the speaker is certain about what he is saying. When it serves this purpose, it's expressing a type of "mood" and thus is called a "modal particle."
Frequently, the statement will include 会 (huì) or 一定会 (yīdìng huì) to emphasize the speaker's certainty.

children.english: He will get better.
You can do this.
She's definitely coming.
We can handle it.
He's not going to apologize.
We've been here before.
I've told you this before. Do you not remember?
I won't lie to you.

关于 (guānyú) means "about." It can be used in a few ways, often marking a topic of a statement or modifying a noun.
As an adverb/adverbial clause, it can only be placed at the beginning of the sentence.

直到 (zhídào) is for describing a time frame that began in the past and continued until a point closer to the present. It is like the English phrase, "all the way until." It can be used in an affirmative or negative form, expressing that something has taken a while or is late. The word 才 (cái) often teams up with 直到, and serves to emphasize the lateness aspect.
In the positive form, which uses 才, it may be more natural in English to express the idea as "not until... did" something happen.
This subject can also be placed before 直到.

children.english: It wasn't until twelve thirty in the morning that I finished my homework.
It took me half a month to recover from the cold.
It wasn't until she was eighteen that she met her biological parents.
It wasn't until I graduated from college that I started living independently.
It wasn't until he went to Beijing that he understood how hard it is to be alone in a big city.

The preposition 给 (gěi) can mean "for," as in, "everything I do, I do it for you." You can also think of it as meaning "give," like to give a service or to give something to someone. In this case, the default position of the character is before the verb, although it sometimes comes after, depending on the verb.

The meaning of 给 is very similar to 为 (wèi) in Chinese, but 给 is more informal than 为, and there are many cases where it's simply based on convention and general practice to decide to use one or the other.
Note that the "recipient" in the pattern above is usually a person but isn't necessarily a person. It could be an animal, company, or any number of other types of recipients.

When you work for a company or do other sorts of physical (and even mental) activities for another party, you're likely to use the Chinese preposition 为 (wèi). This character is often translated into English as "for," but is sometimes unnatural or unnecessary, depending on the particular phrase. For example, the super common Mao-era phrase, 为人民服务 (wèi rénmín fúwù), "serve the people," doesn't need the word "for" in English.
Don't confuse this preposition with 为了, which is a bit different.

children.english: We are all happy for you.
Who has ever considered me?
You guys can come to cheer us on.
She works for the United States government.
This birthday cake has been prepared for you.
The parents have done so much for their family.
Aren't you worried for your child?
Thank you for providing us with so many resources.
He contributed a lot to the development of the company.
Lots of people are praying for those children.

title: Expressing "less than" with "budao"
pattern: 不到 + Number + Measure Word + Noun

blocks.html: The word 到 (dào) means "arrive," but it can also mean "to reach" or "to get to" in an abstract sense. So in this pattern, 不到 (bùdào) means "to not reach (the amount of)," or, to put it another way, "to be less than."

blocks.text: Subj. + 不到 + Number + [Measure Word] + Noun

children.english: My daughter is not yet three years old.
Yesterday I slept for almost five hours.
On this piece of clothing I spent less than 100 RMB.
My house is less than 500 meters from the office.
In the US, if you're under 21 you can't drink alcohol.

blocks.html: When 不到 (bùdào) is put before a time or a duration of time, it needs to be followed with 就 (jiù). This shows that something (usually referring to the past) has happened earlier than expected.

blocks.text: Subj. + 不到 + Time + 就 + Predicate + 了

children.english: Her sickness got better in less than a week.
After knowing each other for less than two months they got married.
Dr. Li retired at under the age of 55.
My grandpa was less than 60 years old when he died.
My boss is less than 30 years old and already has some gray hair.

向 (xiàng) is a preposition that means "towards" and is used often with certain verbs. These usages need to be learned together with 向.
When used as a preposition, 向 indicates an action that is performed towards a reference point but doesn't have any actual motion towards that point.

children.english: Walk to the east.
Look forward.
Turn to the left.
The teacher is currently walking towards us.
The train already departed. She kept waving at me.
You must apologize to him!
You should report this matter to the boss!

children.english: Learn from Comrade Lei Feng!
I don't like to borrow money from friends.
Would you ask strangers for help?
None of us has experience. We're here to ask you for advice.

Although 往 (wǎng) simply means "towards," it's not used as often as certain other prepositions and also has a few special use cases, so it warrants a little extra attention.
往 (wǎng) is a preposition that means "towards" and precedes the verb it modifies.
This is the common one used in everyday speech.
Adding 往 (wǎng) with a location or place word indicates the direction of an action. Remember that the verb comes after this 往 phrase.

children.english: Go straight ahead.
Turn left.
Look up there.
That thief ran towards the east.
Don't throw trash downstairs.
Stop stuffing food in the kid's mouth!

blocks.html: In written language, 往 (wǎng) can also be used after a few monosyllabic verbs, which are then followed by location nouns.

children.english: the train that goes to Beijing
the airplane that flies to New York
cargo that is shipped overseas

blocks.html: 往下 (wǎng xià) expresses "keep going," implying that the process has been interrupted before. The verbs that follow are usually communication or sensory verbs: speak (说), read (读), write (写), watch (看), and listen (听) are common.

children.english: Keep talking.
Keep reading.
Keep reading and you'll see.

You probably already know how to express location with 在. In this article, we'll go more in depth as to how you can make idiomatic phrases using that construction. This kind of form is actually similar to some that we have in English, so it won't be too difficult.
Used with 上
This construction can be translated as "on the topic of" or "in regards to." It can be used to comment on an idea or concept. The examples below will help.
Note that the subject can also be put before 在.

children.english: In regards to this problem, our opinions are the same.
In regards to American history, who is the most important president?
This sentence is okay to say in terms of grammar, it's just not very natural.
There are many differences between northern and southern people when it comes to living habits.

blocks.html: Used with 下
This construction can be translated (rather directly) as "under" and expresses conditions that affected the comment that comes after.

children.english: Do you think kids will be happy growing up in this kind of environment?
Under these kinds of circumstances, what would you do?
In an emergency situation, you can do this.
Under dire financial conditions, she still insisted that the children should all attend school.

blocks.html: Used with 方面
This construction is similar to the 在⋯⋯上 above, which translates to "in relation to" or "on the topic of."

children.english: With regards to career, my boss is very successful.
When it comes to technology, he's an expert.
When it comes to management, you have more experience than I do.
In certain aspects, Chinese and Western culture have a lot in common.

blocks.html: When using 对 (duì) as a preposition, it means "to" or "towards" an object or target. As with all prepositions, you've got to watch out when using this word, as usage of 对 in Chinese doesn't always totally "make sense" or correspond to English at all.
Note that you shouldn't be plugging in just any old verb here; the ones that work with 对 are limited.

children.english: The baby smiled at me.
The dog is barking at you.
You shouldn't talk to your parents this way.
He always lies to his teachers.
Don't lose your temper with the child.

blocks.html: Colloquial Expression 对……来说
In English we often start sentences with "to someone" or "for someone" when sharing that person's perspective. In Chinese, the pattern is:
While this pattern was too common to omit from this page, it's covered in more depth as part of phrases using "laishuo."

Certain verbs, especially psychological verbs, are often used with 对, which means 对 is needed if you want to add an object into the structure. I good example is 对……感兴趣 ("to be interested in..."). In this case, 对 means "in," "on," "about," etc., and the object doesn't have to be a person. The short list below will give a few more verbs frequently paired with 对.

• 对⋯⋯有兴趣 (yǒu xìngqù) to have an interest in...
  • 对⋯⋯感兴趣 (gǎn xìngqù) to feel interested in...
  • 对⋯⋯负责 (fùzé) to be responsible for...
  • 对⋯⋯满意 (mǎnyì) to feel satisfied with...
  • 对⋯⋯失望 (shīwàng) to be disappointed in/with...
  • 对⋯⋯好奇 (hàoqí) to be curious about...

You should be responsible for your job.
The boss is not very satisfied with you.
The audience is very disappointed with the result of the game.
My younger daughter is curious about all animals.

One of the most common ways to express how something "looks" is to use 看起来 (kànqilai). This is what we would use if we wanted to express something like "he looks tired."
This pattern is most commonly followed by an adjectival phrase. This can include regular adverbs of degree like 很, or negative adverbs like 不.

children.english: The cake looks really tasty.
This restaurant looks good.
Your boyfriend looks very mature.
The boss looks a little unhappy.
You look to be about the same height.

blocks.html: If you want to state what something looks like, you'll also need to follow 看起来 with 像 (xiàng), and then the noun phrase.

blocks.text: Subj. + 看起来 + 像 + Noun Phrase

children.english: Your mother is so young! She looks like your older sister.
Do I look like a big boss?
You two look like a couple.
They don't look like rich people.
That drunk guy looks like your husband.

title: Causative verbs
pattern: Subj. + 让 / 叫 / 请 / 使 + Person + Predicate

blocks.html: Causative verbs are used to cause or influence people to do things. In English, these are verbs like "make," "let," "have," and "get," when used in a sentence like "get Billy to eat a live worm."
The most common causative verbs in Chinese are:
The predicate part of the pattern can be a verb or an adjective.
使 (shǐ) and 让 (ràng), when used as causative verbs, basically mean the same thing ("to make"), but 使 (shǐ) is used in more formal or written Chinese, while 让 (ràng) is used more in spoken Chinese.

It's worth noting that 让 is the most common causative verb in spoken Mandarin and is often translated into English as either "make" or "let." It may seem strange to speakers of English that these two very different words are the same word in Chinese. "Make" is kind of like forcing, and "let" is kind of like allowing, right? But in Chinese, the context generally makes clear how willing the object of the causative verb is. It's just something that takes time for learners to get used to.

children.english: Why won't you let me go?
This movie really moves people.
That old man made me think of my grandpa.
He won't listen. What would you have me do?
He secretly asked other girls out. Tell me what I'm supposed to think.
Your son's behavior at school gives the teacher quite a headache.
I want to ask you to do me a favor.
Can I ask you to look after my dog tomorrow?
His speech made the audience very excited.
The financial crisis caused lot of companies to go out of business and also caused many people to lose their jobs.

blocks.html: Obviously, not every causative verb maps perfectly to an English causative verb. You can see from these examples than in some cases the natural English translation doesn't even need a causative verb.

title: Expressing "it depends" with "kan"
pattern: 这 / 那 + 要看 / 得看 + Unclear Situation

blocks.html: Although there are a number of ways to express "it depends" in Chinese, the most common ones in informal spoken Chinese involve the verb 看 (kàn). Some common expressions include 要看 (yào kàn) and 得看 (děi kàn). Both mean "(it) depends (on)." Literally, they would translate as "have to look at," so the logic is not hard to understand.
If you're answering a question with "it depends on..." then this is the pattern you want.

blocks.text: 这 / 那 + 要看 / 得看 + [Unclear Situation]

blocks.html: Keep in mind that the "answers" below are meant to be an answer to some imaginary question that we don't include.

children.english: This depends on when you are available.
That depends on whether he is willing or not.
It depends on how the weather is.
It depends on what the boss thinks.
That depends on the result of the test.

blocks.html: If you're going to write a full sentence explaining what "it" depends on, then you're going to need to lead off with some kind of explanation of the "unknown outcome" of what "it depends" on. So you'll start with the "unknown outcome" in the first part of the sentence (before 要看 / 得看) and then end up with what "it depends on" (after 要看 / 得看).

blocks.text: [Unknown Outcome] + 要看 / 得看 + [Unclear Situation]

blocks.html: The "unknown outcome" normally includes some kind of question word, meaning something like "whether or not x happens" or "what x does," etc.

children.english: Whether or not I go depends on my mood.
When we go depends on the company's arrangements.
Whether to study music or drawing depends on your child's interest.
Whether or not I can stay in China depends on whether or not I can get a visa.
Who the next president will be depends on the result of the election.

blocks.html: If you're looking for more formal language, consider 取决于 (qǔjué yú), "to be determined by."

To express "seems," the word 好像 (hǎoxiàng) can be used.

children.english: He seems to be British.
You don't seem to be a local.
It seems like she's sick.
It seems that you dislike her a lot.
Mr. Wang seems to fear his wife a lot.
He's sitting there all by himself. It seems like he's thinking about something.

blocks.html: Note that if this structure is used without a subject, it has the meaning of "it seems like..." or "it seems that..." in English. This could then be followed by an entire statement.

children.english: It seems like it didn't work.
It seems like it's going to rain.
It seems that someone is knocking at the door.
It seems that someone has been here.

When we talk about mistaken beliefs in English, we just use the word "thought," and the context and the rest of the sentence makes clear that we were wrong. In Chinese, there's a specific verb just for "think mistakenly": 以为 (yǐwéi).

In English, the verb "to think" can apply to both correct and incorrect notions. Chinese has a specific verb for "to mistakenly think that": 以为 (yǐwéi). Literally, these two characters mean, "take to be," i.e. someone takes one thing to be something else.

The part that follows 以为 will be a whole phrase that is actually incorrect information. Note that while it's quite common to refer to things that happened in the past, it could also refer to a situation in the present or even the future. It can also be used for commands, usually of the negative "don't think that..." type.

children.english: I thought he was German.
We thought you weren't at home.
Who do you think you are?
My colleagues all thought I was twenty.
We all thought you were angry.
The teacher thought all the students understood.
Don't think that he's your friend.
She's your grandma? I thought she was your mother.
You went to eat Sichuan hotpot? I thought you don't like eating spicy food.
You guys broke up? I thought you were still together.
I saw that picture and I thought you had a boyfriend.

When 经过 (jīngguò) is used as a verb, it means "to pass by." 经过 can be also used as a preposition to describe what experiences or times one went "through."
As a verb, 经过 means "to pass by" or "to pass through." It's for saying things like, "I passed through downtown" or "I passed by the shop."

children.english: I pass by this place every day on the way to work.
I usually pass by this city when I take the train back to my hometown.
Call me when you pass by my door.
She thinks about him when she walks past this cafe.

blocks.html: As a preposition, 经过 means something like "through" (or "after going through"), and is used to emphasize the process of an experience.

children.english: Through her own hard work, she was admitted into Peking University.
After two months of preparation, he successfully passed the job interview.
After the last few years of development, this city has changed a lot.
After one week of investigation, the police believe that he's not guilty.

blocks.html: The first meaning of 通过 (tōngguò) used as a verb is "to go through" a certain object, as in penetrating into and coming out of something. The second meaning is "to pass," which means someone goes through effort in order to reach acknowledgment or agreement.

children.english: To get there from my house, you have to cross two bridges.
Go through that red door, turn left and you are there.
I passed this test.
He didn't pass yesterday's job interview.
That man in black didn't pass the security check at the airport.

blocks.html: As a preposition, 通过 expresses using a certain method to achieve a desired outcome. It emphasizes the manner or method of doing something, and it can be placed before or after the subject.

children.english: We found him via his friends.
Through this survey, we found that many people support him.
We've got a better understanding of your company through this short film.
Through his introduction, I met my current boss.
Our employees have become more professional through monthly trainings.

来自 (láizì) is used to express the origin of something or someone. Its meaning is similar to "to come from" in English.
You can see that in some of the sentences below dealing with ideas and other abstract nouns, a translation like "originate from" may be more appropriate.

The word 算 (suàn) has a number of uses which can be translated in a number of ways. The common theme is that 算 indicates some kind of judgment and may be thought of as "counts as" or "is considered to be."
This essentially expresses that one "considers" something to be something else, as in, "I consider her a genius."

children.english: She is considered a genius.
Is this considered a secret?
Can she be considered your girlfriend or not?
Can American Chinese food be considered Chinese food?
We know each other, but can't be considered friends.

blocks.html: 算 can also be used with an adjective. It adds a sense of "comparatively speaking," as in, "in the grand scheme of things, this counts as...."

children.english: The things in this shop are pretty cheap.
My daughter pretty much does what she's told.
I'm considered young in our company.
Your boss could be said to be generous. My boss is even stingier.

blocks.html: This is essentially a straight negation of the affirmative form, but because it's so commonly used, it's worth giving providing extra examples.
Note that you don't need add a 的 here.

children.english: This exam isn't that difficult.
Getting married when you're 30 can't be considered late.
He's only 1.75 meters tall. He can't be considered very tall.
Fifty kuai for a haircut. It can't be considered expensive.

blocks.html: Adding a Tone of Reluctance with 算是
blocks.text: Adding a Tone of Reluctance with 算是

blocks.html: For both the noun and adjective patterns above, the "judgment" indicated by 算 can be made more reluctant by following 算 immediately with a 是.

children.english: He is considered a genius.
You could say he's a genius (I guess).
Well aren't you tough!
So you think you're some kind of big shot?
It's no big deal.

blocks.html: The verb 来 (lái) can be used as a "dummy verb," similar to the way "do" is used in English. To illustrate the point, imagine a bottle of pickles that you want to open but can't because the lid is so tight. You start passing it around to see who can open it, and no one is able to, until your beefy friend comes in and says, "我来!" He is saying, "Let me do it!"

The structure for using 来 as a dummy verb is very basic. Usually it is a very short phrase, kind of like "your turn!" or "let me give it a shot!" or "you do it!" in English. Usually it is used with 你 or 我 as the subject, and it ends with the 来. Sometimes it can end with a 吧.
The point of calling 来 a "dummy verb" is that it does't have the original meaning of "to come." It just takes the place of whatever the verb would be in the context.

children.english: You do it!
Let me do it.
Let him do it himself.
It's better that you do it by yourselves.
You write well. You write it.

In Chinese, 要 (yào) has many meanings, one of which is "need to." However, when you want to express "don't need to," you actually use 不用 (bùyòng), not 不要 (bùyào).

children.english: You don't need to thank me.
You don't need to worry.
Kids don't need to buy tickets.
You don't need to go over there. She will come here.
We don't need to work overtime today.
You don't need to tell him about this.
Tell him that he doesn't need to come tomorrow.
Buy it. You don't need to consider the price.
There aren't many people today. We don't need to wait in line.
Not all of you need to come. We don't need this many people.

blocks.html: In spoken Chinese, the rhetorical question, "这还用说吗？" indicates the speaker believes that the statement is obvious. It is equivalent to the speaker saying, "does that even need to be said?" or "is that seriously a question?" This 用 is the direct opposite of the 不用 in this grammar point, but you don't hear it a lot.

Normally, when you see 得, it's a particle and is pronounced "de." However, it can also be an auxiliary verb. In this case it's pronounced "děi" and means "must."

The word 少 (shǎo) can mean "few," but when placed before a verb, it takes on the meaning of "less" as in "to do less (of something)." It is often heard when scolding or giving advice (like when parents talk to children). What's not intuitive to learners is that the word 少 should come before the verb.
Just as you can use 多 to talk about doing something more, you can use 少 to talk about doing something less.

Note that in English, we don't use the word "less" very much. For example, rather than saying "drink less water," we might say "don't drink so much water." In Chinese, though, using 少 is quite natural and common. Avoiding the negative command (telling someone not to do something) is also a subtle way of sounding less bossy and annoying in Chinese.

children.english: Use less salt, please.
Eat less junk food.
Don't buy too much. It will go bad if we can't finish eating it all.
Can you smoke less?
The mid-term exams are coming up. Go easy on the video games.
Don't drink so much. You need go to work tomorrow.
Watch less TV. Read more books.
Eat less meat and eat more vegetables.

children.explanation: Lit. "come less"

children.explanation: Lit. "speak less nonsense talk"
children.english: Quit your babbling!

children.explanation: Lit. "get involved less in others' affairs"
children.english: Stay out of other people's business.

In China, you often hear you should do this or that more (eat more, drink more water, wear more warm clothing, etc.), and they often use the word 多 (duō). What's not intuitive to learners is that the word 多 should come before the verb.
This structure is often used in commands or suggestions.  Note the position of 多:
This structure is not used exclusively as a command, so you could also include a subject if you needed to.

In English we like to say things like "eat more," "drink more beer," and "I need to exercise more." Notice that in every one of these cases, the word "more" (equivalent to this use of 多) comes after the verb in English. In Chinese, it's more natural to put the 多 before the verb.

children.english: Eat a little more.
Add a little more spiciness.
Take more.
Gramps, you need to go out and take walks more often.
Give him a little more time.
I want to spend more time with my family.
Drink more water when you have a cold.
The doctor told me to exercise more.
He's more experienced than you. You should learn from him more.
If you want to improve your spoken Chinese, you need to practice more.

The opposite of 多 is, of course, 少. It is further explained in the article doing something less with "shao".

title: Expressing actions in progress (full form)

blocks.html: You may have learned that 在 (zài) and 正在 (zhèngzài) can be used before verbs to express that an action is ongoing or in progress. They are used to create the Mandarin equivalent of present continuous in English. But that pattern is actually a part of a longer, fuller pattern. It's rarely used in its full form, but bits and pieces of it are frequently used in everyday speech, so it's important to know the full form, even if you don't use it regularly yourself.

blocks.text: Subj. + 正在 / 正 / 在 + Verb + 呢

blocks.html: If it's a Separable verb, you need to put the 着 between the verb and the object, or you can just leave 着 out.

blocks.text: Subj. (+ 正) + Verb + 着 + Obj. + 呢

The most common variation is just the "在 + V" pattern that you probably already learned long ago. Another common variation is "正 + V" pattern.

You might be tempted to conclude that 不怎么 (bù zěnme) seems to mean "not how," but it actually means "not often" when used together with a verb.

When 不怎么 is used with a verb, it means that one does not put a lot of time or energy into doing it. In other words, the action is done "not often." When the verb is used with an object, it also means that the number (or quantity) is really small.

children.english: He doesn't like to talk much.
My husband doesn't exercise much.
We don't watch a lot of television at home.
My son doesn't snack much.
My boss doesn't come to the office very often.
I don't online shop very often.
They don't often go out with friends.

blocks.html: Usage of 没怎么
Note that the examples below use 没 instead of 不. This is because the verb uses or implies 有 and thus it uses the same the 有 negation rules.

children.english: I didn't review much.
I didn't really think about this before.
My stomach didn't feel well yesterday, so I didn't eat much.

blocks.html: Lastly, make sure to use 不怎么 with a verb if you want it to mean "not often." Using it with an adjective gives it a different meaning.

One kind of complement in Chinese involves putting 到 (dào) after the verb, followed by a time or other event. This 到 works much like the English word "until."

blocks.text: Verb (+ 一直) + 到 + Time / Event

blocks.html: You will sometimes see 一直 (yīzhí) proceeding 到, which serves the purpose of the emphasis on the "ongoing duration."
Note that the verbs are mostly single-syllable.

children.english: When will you be done playing?
We were chatting in the bar until midnight.
Your younger brother is going to stay in our house until when?
Yesterday's meeting lasted until 9 pm.
My neighbors had a fight today, which lasted until the police came.
We went to eat hotpot tonight, and we didn't finish until the place was closed.
He was playing computer games all day yesterday. He didn't stop until his mother came home.

blocks.text: [Verb Phrase] (+ 一直) + Verb + 到 + Time / Event

children.english: Do you know we waited for you until midnight?
My daughter didn't finish her homework until 12:30 last night.
She called her boyfriend and they kept talking until her phone was out of battery.

When a verb is done more than once, it also requires a measure word to accompany it. This way the measure word is acting as a way to count the frequency or re-occurrence of an action. The most basic one you probably already know is 次 (cì).

The grammar pattern is very similar to English. For example, "看三次" and "saw three times" mirror each other in structure. In Chinese sentences, these measure words come after the verb. You should also know that, like nouns, some verbs have special measure words to go with them. The basic verbal measure word, however, is 次, as in the number of "times" something is done or happens.
Common verb measure words include 次 (cì), 遍 (biàn), and 下 (xià).

children.english: Say it again.
Could you please read it again?
I've seen this movie twice.

I've asked him about it many times, but he won't tell me.
We've discussed this issue a few times.
That red-haired boy hit me three times.
He very lightly pat me a few times.
Did you not hear the door? I knocked quite a few times.
