title: Expressing comparable degree with "you"
pattern: Noun 1 有 Noun 2 + Adj. + 吗？

blocks.html: 有 (yǒu), besides just meaning "to have," can also be used in comparisons. It's what you use instead of 比 (bǐ) if something is "as [Adj.] as" something else.

The structure literally means, "A has B's [Adj.]." The meaning is "A is as [Adj.] as B." This pattern is often used in questions. Think of the jealous girl asking, "is she as pretty as me?" or the insecure weightlifter bro asking, "is he as jacked as me?" Note that for this kind of question, B is usually the one that the speaker prefers.

blocks.text: A + 有 + B + Adj. + 吗 ？

blocks.html: This comparison pattern is generally only used in questions, not statements.

children.english: Is he as handsome as me?
Are you as busy as the boss?
Is he as tall as YaoMing?
Is the population of New York city as big as that of Shanghai?

blocks.html: If a verb is included in this pattern to talk about an action, it's probably going to involve a degree complement using this structure below:

blocks.text: A + 有 + B + Verb + 得 + Adj. + 吗 ？

children.english: Can he do it as well as I do?
Can you run as fast as Bolt does?

blocks.html: Advanced Pattern Using 这么 / 那么
blocks.text: Advanced Pattern Using 这么 / 那么

blocks.html: This form is often used with 这么 or 那么, which in this case means "as much." And it indicates that B is already very [Adj.]. When B is absent, 那么 means "so" or "that".

blocks.text: A + 有 (+ B) + 这么 / 那么 + Adj. + 吗 ？

children.english: Is she really that pretty?
Is this medicine really that magical?
Is he really as tall as YaoMing?
Are you as rich as Bill Gates?

If you want to do a straight-up comparison statement, go ahead and use the classic 比 (bǐ) structure. But if you want to lead with a "compared with..." phrase, you'll need a 跟 (gēn) and a slightly different word order.
This sentence structure is used for comparing one thing as it relates to another.
These patterns are for making a comment about B, as it relates to A.
B can also come at the beginning of the sentence:

blocks.text: B + 跟 + A + 比 (起来) ，⋯⋯

blocks.html: For both of these structures, you could swap out 跟 (gēn) for 和 (hé) with no real difference, but using 跟 (gēn) is slightly more common.

children.english: Compared to Shanghai, prices in my hometown are very low.
Compared to the eastern USA, I like the western USA more.
Compared to him, what is your biggest advantage?
Compared to the older sister, the younger sister is a bit shy.
Compared with the old version, the new version has a few more features.

blocks.html: Used with a Single Subject
比 (bǐ) can also be used for comparing one subject over two different time periods.
Again, you could use 和 (hé) instead of 跟 (gēn) here, but using 跟 (gēn) is more common.

children.english: Compared to last year, your Chinese has improved a lot.
Compared to ten years ago, the standard of living for Chinese people has gotten much better.
Compared with last month, this month our work is a lot more relaxed.
Compared to the past few weeks, the weather has been much more comfortable this week.
Compared to when he first graduated, he's much more mature.

title: Expressing "even more" with "geng" or "hai"
pattern: Noun 1 + 比 + Noun 2 + 更 / 还 + Adj.

blocks.html: When used in a comparison, 更 (gèng) or 还 (hái) can kick up an adjective to an even higher degree. For example, New York City is America's biggest city with a population of around 9 million. Shanghai is China's biggest city, with a population of more than 20 million. So even though NYC's population is big, Shanghai's is even bigger. You'd use 更 or 还 to express this in Chinese.

blocks.text: Noun 1 + 比 + Noun 2 + 更 / 还 + Adj.

children.english: Shanghai's population is even bigger than New York's.
My younger sister is even skinnier than me.
My cat is even naughtier than my dog.
Sometimes animals are even smarter than human beings.
There are even more job opportunities in big cities than in my hometown.
He is even taller than Yao Ming.

children.explanation: 38 ºC = 100 ºF
children.english: It was 38 degrees yesterday, and it's even hotter today.
This foreigner speaks even more authentic Chinese than native speakers do.

blocks.html: 还 has a more intense tone, and it usually carries a tone of surprise and skepticism. Therefore, using the form of a rhetorical question with 还 can be understood as "how can it be?"
Also note that 更 can be used with 了 in this pattern, indicating change of situation or state, while 还 can't  be used in this way.

children.english: This place is even livelier than before.

title: Expressing "much more" in comparisons
pattern: Noun 1 + 比 + Noun 2 + Adj. + 多了

blocks.html: If you want to up the contrast of your comparisons, you might want to express "much more." You can do this using 多 (duō), but did you know there are actually three different ways to do it?

As well as expressing that two things differ, you might want to go further and say that they differ a lot by adding 很多 (hěn duō), 多了(duō le), or 得多 (de duō). This is like saying that one thing is much more Adj. than another in English.

blocks.text: Noun 1 + 比 + Noun 2 + Adj. + 很多 / 得多 / 多了

children.english: Pinyin is much easier than Chinese characters.
It's much more convenient to take the high-speed train than the airplane.
This female teacher is much stricter than that male teacher.
My wife's salary is much higher than mine.
You're much more experienced than me.
You're much luckier than us.
He plays basketball much better than I do.

blocks.html: Short Form with 多了
Given sufficient context, it's possible to use 多了 without the full comparison pattern. 多了 is the only one of the three "much more" phrases introduced in this article which can be used this way.

children.explanation: We both know I've had this bad cold.
children.english: My cold is getting much better.

children.explanation: We're both aware of recent weather, obviously.
children.english: It's been much warmer lately.

children.explanation: We both know how immature she used to be.
children.english: She became much more mature after she went to college.

When conceding a point, we often put emphasis on the point we are conceding, and in Chinese, there is a way to do that with 是 (shì).

This pattern is often used in an argument or debate. It's usually indicating that the speaker is conceding a point, but they still have some reservations about the topic at hand. Don't worry, the examples will make this clear.

blocks.text: Adj. + 是 + Adj. ， 但是 / 就是 ⋯⋯

children.english: Work may be busy, but I'm very happy.
This piece of clothing may look nice, but it doesn't suit me.
This environment may be nice, but transportation is not very convenient.
It may be tiring, but it's really worth it.
It is difficult, but I believe that I can do it.

blocks.html: When using 但是, the second clause can express positive experiences or something good, as well as negative perspectives. However, when leading with 就是, the second clause needs to express something negative.

children.english: It may be tasty, it's just that it's not very healthy.
This thing may be good, it's just that it's too expensive.
This student may be smart, it's just that he's not very hard-working.
His girlfriend may be pretty, it's just that she's is a little weird.
This teacher may teach well; it's just that she's too strict.

title: Events in quick succession with "yi... jiu..."

blocks.html: This pattern tells us that as soon as one thing happens, then another thing happens immediately afterwards. You mark the two events with 一 (yī) and 就 (jiù).
The pattern involves two different events, the first preceded by "一," and then the second event, which follows in quick succession, preceded by 就.
The subjects of the two "Events" can be the same, but they don't have to be. If they're the same, then you don't need to repeat the subject for the second one.

children.english: I'm starving. I'm going to have lunch as soon as class is over.
Can you go to pick up our kid as soon as you get off work?
As soon as mom arrived home, she went off to cook.
As soon as the teacher came , everyone stopped talking.
As soon as I walked in the door, the puppy ran over to me.

blocks.html: In this case, 一 means "every time," followed by some certain condition, which could be the reason or the cause of what happens after 就. The subjects of the two "Events" are usually the same.

children.english: Every time I think about this, I get upset.
Every time she gets angry, her face turns red.
How come you get diarrhea every time you eat hotpot?
Every time he has English class, he feels like falling asleep.
Every time we talk about physics, it gives me a headache.

The grammar pattern 虽然⋯⋯ 但是⋯⋯ (suīrán... dànshì...) is one of the most commonly used patterns in Chinese, especially in written Chinese. You can think of it as meaning "although," but unlike in English, you still need to follow it up with a "but" word in Chinese.
虽然⋯⋯ 但是⋯⋯ expresses that while the former part of the sentence is true, there is an adverse reaction in the latter part.

Simply put, the pattern means, although..., but... In English, you wouldn't normally need the "but" there, but it is required in Chinese. Be aware that 可是 can be used interchangeably with 但是 for the "but" part. Also note that 还是 can be used after 但是 for emphasis, meaning "still."

children.english: Although it's cold outside, it's warm inside.
Although this piece of clothing is a little expensive, the quality is good.
Although he didn't want to go, he ended up going.
Even though his family is rich, he never wastes money.
Although my little sister is fat, she is flexible.
Although she has prepared very well, she's still a little nervous.
Although you're well-educated, you don't have work experience.
Although grandma is in her eighties, she is energetic.
Although you didn't win, I know that all of you did your best.
Although I've known him for a long time, I still don't know him well.

要么 (yàome) is used for offering a pair of choices with a hardline "either/or" feel: these are the two choices. Choose one. (It can also be used for more than two choices, but it's usually just two.)
You can give a series of alternatives by using 要么 (yàome). The structure is pretty versatile, as you can put a wide variety of things after each 要么. It can be used both for commands and non-commands.

Either keeping looking for a job or start your own business. You can't do nothing.
Last summer I either went to the gym or the library every day. It was super boring.
My husband either sleeps or plays video games on weekends. He never does housework.

title: Expressing "except" and "in addition" with "chule… yiwai"
pattern: 除了 ⋯⋯ (+ 以外) ，Subj. + 都 / 也 / 还 ⋯⋯

blocks.html: Using 除了 (chúle)--often with 以外 (yǐwài)--will help you spruce up your sentences when you want to express the meanings of "except," "besides," or "in addition." You may feel that "except" has a pretty different meaning from the other two. Well, read on!
除了⋯⋯ (以外), 都⋯⋯ is a pattern used to express "except." Make a special note of the 都 (dōu)!
以外 can be omitted from the pattern without changing its meaning.

children.english: Except for him, we've all been there.
He drinks all kinds of alcohol except baijiu.
Except for weekends, the boss works overtime every day.
We're satisfied with all aspects except for the price.
I read all types of news except for political news.

blocks.html: 除了⋯⋯ (以外), 也/还⋯⋯ is used to express "in addition." Make a special note of the 也 or 还!

blocks.text: 除了 ⋯⋯ (+ 以外) ，Subj. + 也 / 还 ⋯⋯

In addition to sports, what other hobbies do you have?
In addition to a cat and a dog, I also had a rabbit.
In addition to seafood, what else are you allergic to?

title: Expressing good luck with "haihao"
pattern: 还好 + Lucky Incident ，不然 + Bad Outcome

blocks.html: 还好 (háihǎo) can mean "fortunately" or "luckily." Another good translation would be "it's a good thing that...." It is often followed with 不然, which precedes the bad thing that could have happened if not for the stroke of luck.

children.english: Luckily, we came by taxi. Otherwise we would have been late.
It's a good thing that my mother didn't see it. Otherwise she would definitely be mad.
Fortunately you're here. Otherwise I really wouldn't have known what to do.
It's a good thing I brought the umbrella. Otherwise, I would have definitely gotten soaked.
Luckily, we bought a lot. Otherwise, there wouldn't have been enough.
It's a good thing I didn't listen to him. Otherwise, I would have lost.
Luckily, I saved it. Otherwise, I would have lost all of the documents.
It's a good thing I didn't order that much food. Otherwise, it would have all been wasted.
Luckily, the boss doesn't know about it. Otherwise, you would definitely get fired.
It's a good thing you reminded me. Otherwise, I would have definitely forgotten.

The 如果 ⋯⋯，就⋯⋯ (rúguǒ..., jiù...) two-part structure is very logical and concise, meaning "if... then...."

如果⋯⋯，就⋯⋯ is an often-used pattern that is utilized in the same way that "If…, then…" is in English. In English we sometimes drop then "then" in the second half of the sentence, and you can do the same in Chinese, dropping the 就.

children.english: If there is any difficulty, give me a call.
If you lose, give me 100 kuai.
If you can't find it, then buy a new one.
If he keeps showing up, we'll call the police.
If you no longer love each other, just break up.

blocks.html: Alternate Pattern Using 那么
Sometimes 那么 (nàme) is used instead of 就 (jiù), imparting a more relaxed, informal feel to the sentence. Sometimes just 那 (nà) will be used instead of 那么 (nàme).

children.english: If he knew, he would definitely tell me.
If none of you are interested, I will stop talking.
If you really want to work with us, then we should schedule a day to discuss it.
If we can find the investment, we'll be able to get on it next month.
If you want to apply, you need to start to prepare right away.

blocks.html: 如果⋯⋯的话 (rúguǒ... dehuà) is a pattern commonly used in Chinese to express "if." An easy way to remember the pattern's format is that in the full form, the condition is "sandwiched" between 如果 and 的话.
Note that 就 (jiù) is often optional. For more on using 如果 with 就, check out the "if…, then…" two-part pattern with 如果……就…….

children.english: If it rains tomorrow, we won't go.
Don't order so much. It will be a big waste of food if we can't finish it all.
If someone had helped him, he would't have had this accident.
If you don't come, you'll definitely regret it.
What will you do if he doesn't agree?

blocks.html: Colloquially, it's also possible to drop the 如果 and just use the 的话 instead to mean "if." 的话 is optional.

children.english: Don't go if you don't feel like going.
If you think it's tasty, eat some more.
Take it if you like it.

blocks.html: It's even possible to use neither 的话 nor 就, and let the "if" be completely implied.

children.english: Give me a call if you need anything.
If you're free, come to my place and hang out.

blocks.html: Note that 如果 can be switched out for the various other terms for "if," including the common 要是 (yàoshi) and the formal 假如 (jiǎrú), among others.

title: Expressing "not only... but also" with "budan... erqie..."

blocks.html: 不但⋯⋯，而且⋯⋯ (bùdàn..., érqiě...) is a very commonly used pattern that indicates "not only, ... but also...."
The same subject should apply to both the first part and the second part (the part after 而且). The pattern can also be used omitting 而且, and instead using adverbs like 也 and 还 in its place.

children.english: This thing is not only expensive, but also hard to buy.
This dish is not only attractive, but also delicious.
She is not only smart, but also very humorous.
Not only did she leave me, but she also took all my money.
Not only did he finish it in advance, but he did it very well.

blocks.html: When there is only one subject with 不但⋯⋯而且⋯⋯, the subject has to come at the beginning of the sentence, before both 不但 and 而且. When using two different subjects, however, you need to put one after 不但 and one after 而且.

blocks.text: 不但 + Subj. 1 ⋯⋯ ，而且 + Subj. 2 + 也 ⋯⋯

blocks.html: The pattern can also be used omitting 而且, and instead using adverbs like 也 in its place.

children.english: Not only is it hard to find a job for undergraduates, but it's also hard for graduate students.
Not only do children like this movie, but adults like it too.
Not only are the employees under a lot of pressure, but the boss is under a lot of pressure too.
The teacher found that not only did the student lie, but his parents did too.
Not only do ordinary folk fear these people, but the police fear them too.

blocks.html: 怪不得 (guàibude) can be used to express that the speaker finds something unsurprising. It can be used alone or in a variety of different structures, as shown below. 难怪 (nánguài) is another way to express the exact same thing.
Emphasis on 怪不得 / 难怪
blocks.text: Emphasis on 怪不得 / 难怪

blocks.html: 怪不得 is used to convey the speaker's newfound understanding of a situation, having recently acquired some new information that, in his opinion, explains it.
怪不得 can be replaced with 难怪 in the structure without altering its meaning.

children.english: Little Zhang asked for vacation time, no wonder I haven't seen him today.
He's late for work every day. No wonder he got fired.
She's your younger sister? No wonder you two look so much alike.
Your cell phone is out of power? No wonder my call wouldn't go through.
You put vinegar in it? No wonder it tastes so bad!

blocks.html: Emphasis on 原来

blocks.text: 怪不得 / 难怪 + [Observation] ，原来 (+ 是) + Reason

children.english: No wonder the students don't like this teacher. He gives too much homework.
No wonder you two look so happy. You are getting married.
No wonder there are so many people here. There's a sale going on.
No wonder she got a diarrhea. She went to eat hotpot again yesterday.
No wonder he hasn't told me. He doesn't want me to worry about this.

blocks.html: The Other Meaning of 难怪
blocks.text: The Other Meaning of 难怪

blocks.html: This usage is definitely less common, but sometimes 难怪 is a combination of the 难 + Verb pattern and the verb 怪, meaning "to blame." In this case, the meaning is totally different. Although it's not as common, and you shouldn't need to worry about it too much, we include it here because if you ever run into and think that 难怪 can only ever have one meaning, it can totally throw you for a loop.

children.english: We can't really blame him. He's so young.
We can't really blame everybody. It was such short notice.

blocks.html: When used in this way it expresses that the speaker assigns no blame in the situation he is describing. Sometimes the specific person undeserving of blame is mentioned directly after 难怪, but not always.

When talking about various aspects of a situation, 一方面⋯⋯， (另)一方面⋯⋯ (yī fāngmiàn..., (lìng) yī fāngmiàn...) can be used in a way similar to how "on one hand..., on the other hand..." is used in English.

blocks.text: 一 方面 ⋯⋯ ， (另) 一 方面 ⋯⋯

blocks.html: The two aspects in the sentence can both be similar in tone, and they can also be in direct opposition to each other. You will often see the adverb 又,  也 or 还 following 另一方面, which serves the purpose of emphasis.

children.english: On one hand, cooking for yourself is  healthy; on the other hand, it can also help to save some money.

On the one hand, we don't want to do it this way; on the other hand, we must do it this way.
On one hand, smoking can do harm to the smoker himself; on the other hand, it can also do harm to people around him.
On the one hand, using smart phones is very convenient; on the other hand, they also make it very easy to waste a lot of time.
One the one hand, we need to satisfy our clients, but on the other hand, we also need to control our costs.
On one hand, their service is very professional; on the other hand, their price is also reasonable.
On one hand, we can save time by doing it this way; on the other hand, we can improve the quality.
One one hand, this project can increase local people's income; on the other hand, it can protect the local environment.
On the one hand, the government needs to develop these old towns; on the other hand, they need to protect them too.

title: Expressing "when" with "dengdao"
pattern: 等(到) + Time / Event ，Subj. + 再 / 就 ⋯⋯

blocks.html: The word 等到 (děngdào) can trip up learners, because while it can literally mean "to wait until," it also has the less literal translation meaning "when (the time comes)" or "by the time (something happens)." This is a pattern that appears in complex sentences, with 等到 acting as a conjunction and appearing in the first part as the first word in the sentence.
When talking about the future, the second part of the sentence uses 就 (jiù) or 再 (zài).

blocks.text: 等(到) + Time / Event ，Subj. + 再 / 就 + Predicate

blocks.html: The predicate part of the pattern can be a verb or an adjective.

children.english: When the boss finds out, we'll be in trouble.
When the rain stops, I'll go outside.
When autumn arrives, these leaves will turn yellow.
I will take a vacation when I finish this project.
I will make arrangements once the boss signs off on it.

blocks.html: For the past, the second part of the sentence uses 才 (cái). This pattern is very similar to how 直到 (zhídào) is used to mean "all the way until", and also overlaps with the use of 才 to express lateness.

blocks.text: 等(到) + Time / Event ，Subj. + 才 + Predicate

children.english: I didn't realize I left my cell phone in the taxi until I got home.
She didn't start working until her children had started elementary school.
The teacher didn't begin the class until the students all became quiet.
It wasn't until he had had a child that he realized how hard it is to be a parent.
It wasn't until he got home that he found that he didn't have his keys.

Both 常常 (chángcháng) and 经常 (jīngcháng) are adverbs expressing the idea of "often," though their usage differs in some small details.
常常 and 经常 both can be used to express frequency, meaning "often," and that the time between each instance something happens is very short. In this case, they are interchangeable.

children.english: I often receive spam texts.
Do you guys often work overtime?
They often argue.

blocks.html: Neither 常常 nor 经常 can be placed before the subject:

children.english: He often skips breakfast.

blocks.html: Note that 常 (by itself) is used for future frequent actions in colloquial Chinese.

children.english: Come hang out often!
Let's keep in touch!

blocks.html: Although not so commonly used in this way, 经常 can also be used as an adjective referring to things that happens very frequently. 常常 can't be used this way.

children.english: It's a regular thing for her to forget to bring her keys.

blocks.html: 经常 and 常常 can share the same negative form 不常. You can also simply use 不 to negate both 经常 and 常常, although 不常常 is not super common.

children.english: He doesn't smoke very often.
My mother doesn't often shop online.

刚 (gāng) and 刚才 (gāngcái) have similar meanings of "just (now)," but they differ on a few key uses.

刚 is actually an adverb, and it is placed in front of the verb. It emphasizes that the action just happened a short time ago. Unsurprisingly, it is similar to the English "just." 刚刚 and 刚 are interchangeable in this case.

The key here is that "a short time ago" is relative and determined by the speaker. For this reason, 刚 can indicate that something "just" happened 1 second ago, 5 minutes ago, 2 hours ago, 3 weeks ago, or even a year ago. The absolute time is flexible, but from the speaker's perspective, it feels recent.
刚 Before a Verb
One thing that confuses a lot of learners is that when you use 刚 with a verb, you normally don't need 了. Keep that in mind while reading the following examples, and look for the explanation below.

children.explanation: This gives the impression that not only did he just get here, but he should still be here.
children.english: He just arrived.
We just arrived yesterday.
What bad timing. The boss just left.

blocks.html: It would be wrong to use 刚才 instead:

children.explanation: 刚才 should be used for events a lot closer in time than 昨天.

blocks.html: And if you mean to say "when I first arrived in Shanghai," use 刚 instead of 刚才:

children.english: I didn't know anyone when I had just arrived in Shanghai.

blocks.html: 刚 or 刚刚 before An Adjective
blocks.text: 刚 or 刚刚 before An Adjective

blocks.html: 刚, as an adverb, can also be placed in front of a verb, while 刚才 can't be used this way. 刚 can also be used interchangeably with 刚刚.

children.english: He just recovered from his cold.
The sky just became clear.
The beef just got cooked.

blocks.html: 刚才 is a time noun (like 今天 and 现在), and it expresses that the time elapsed is really short, in near-absolute terms. We're talking no more than 1-30 minutes in most situations, and often less than 5 minutes. When used before a verb, 刚才 emphasizes something happened "just now."

children.explanation: He was crying a moment ago but he stopped.
children.english: He was crying just now.

children.explanation: Sounds like he's not here anymore; I just saw him, but don't see him now.
children.english: I just now saw him.
I feel a little better now than just before.

blocks.html: 刚才, as a time noun, can directly modify a noun to indicate it is that one from "just now" or "just before," while 刚 can't be used this way.

children.english: What just happened is really upsetting.
What just happened is really upsetting.

blocks.html: 刚 and 刚才 with 了
blocks.text: 刚 and 刚才 with 了

blocks.html: You may have noticed that something interesting is going on with regards to 了 in the sentences with 刚 and 刚才. Namely, 了 is not usually required in sentences with 刚, but it is usually required in sentences with 刚才. This is because 刚才 refers to a time in the recent past, and you're usually indicated that something happened just now (started and finished).

children.english: I looked at it yesterday.
I looked at it just now.

blocks.html: So these are both simple "subject + verb" sentences. Notice that when they refer to the past (including the one with 刚才), the action is completed and you need 了. You don't need 了 for things that haven't happened yet (they're just plans, and nothing is completed). And remember that 刚才 always refers to the past.
OK, now what about 刚? Why does it not need 了? The key is that you don't need a 了 in a sentence with 刚 if the verb already indicates a clear result. So, to use the 看 example from above:

children.explanation: Adding a 到 to 看 gives the verb a meaning of the result of "looking at."
children.english: I just saw it.

children.explanation: 了 is not needed here as 看到 includes the result of "looking at."
children.english: I just saw it.

children.explanation: 了 is needed with 刚才 because it feels so recent and unresolved.
children.english: I saw it just now.

children.explanation: The verb 到 includes a clear result.
children.english: I just arrived.

children.explanation: The verb 知道 always includes the result of "knowing."
children.english: You just found out?

children.explanation: The verb 醒 includes a clear enough indication of result.
children.english: The baby just woke up.

blocks.html: 刚 and 刚才 with 没
blocks.text: 刚 and 刚才 with 没

blocks.html: There's also something going on with 没 in sentences with 刚 and 刚才. The deal here is that you can say something didn't happen just now (刚才), but you can't say that something just didn't happen (刚). [Saying that something "just didn't happen" only works in English if you interpret "just" to mean "simply."]
The takeaway? Just don't use 刚 in sentences where you use 没 to negate the past.

children.explanation: Don't use 刚 with 没 in the past.
children.english: I just didn't see it.
I didn't understand just now.

blocks.html: Use 没 with 刚才 (and no 了) to negate the past.

children.english: I didn't see it just now.
I didn't understand just now.

children.speaker: A
children.english: Where did you go just now?

children.speaker: B
children.english: I went to the bathroom. I just got back.

一点 (yīdiǎn) and 有点 (yǒudiǎn), usually pronounced 一点儿 (yīdiǎnr) and 有点儿 (yǒudiǎnr) in northern China, mean pretty much the same thing on the surface—"a little" or "a bit"—but they have different uses in sentences.
Both Can Be Used for Describing Degree
blocks.text: Both Can Be Used for Describing Degree

blocks.html: Usage of 有点

有点 is placed before an adjective, and while used for descriptions, it also expresses a tone of complaint by the speaker, or some other form of negative impression. It doesn't just mean "a bit," but rather "a bit too" (for the speaker's liking).

children.explanation: This is a complaint.
children.english: I am a little tired today.

children.explanation: This is a complaint.
children.english: This dish is a bit salty.

blocks.html: Usage of 一点

一点 can't be placed before an adjective. Instead, it is placed after adjectives. The adjectives that can be used are particularly limited. 一点 is often used when comparing, requesting, or expressing the speaker’s expectation. In this usage, 一点 can also be shortened to just 点。

children.explanation: This is a request.
children.english: Please speak a little more slowly.

children.explanation: This is a request.
children.english: Hurry up a bit, we're going to be late.

children.explanation: This is a request.
children.english: Boss [shop owner], a little cheaper, please.

children.explanation: This is a comparison.
children.english: This one is a bit heavier than that one.

blocks.html: Use 有(一)点 for Describing Quantity
blocks.text: Use 有(一)点 for Describing Quantity

blocks.html: 一点 can be placed before a noun to mean "small quantity," like 一点水，一点钱 while 有点 can't be used this way. Note that 有点 is also a shortened form of 有一点, which means "there is a little" of something.
A few examples to help you understand:

children.english: There's a little ketchup on your face.
There's still a little rice in your bowl. Finish eating it.

blocks.html: Use 有点 Before Just 不 or 没
blocks.text: Use 有点 Before Just 不 or 没

blocks.html: After 有点, you can use 不 or 没 before the adjective, however the adjective should have a positive connotation, like 高兴 (gāoxìng), 舒服 (shūfu), 喜欢 (xǐhuan), etc. This makes the overall emotion expressed  negative still.

children.english: The children don't really like our new home.
She doesn't feel very well.
I don't really believe that guy.
We didn't really understand what was said.

blocks.html: Use 一点 Before 也不 or 也没
blocks.text: Use 一点 Before 也不 or 也没

blocks.html: 一点 can also be used in the 一点也不 or 一点也没 structure to mean "not at all."

children.english: This dish is not spicy at all.
You didn't do any homework at all?

children.explanation: This is a complaint.
children.english: It's a little hot today.

children.explanation: This is a complaint.
children.english: I'm a little hungry.

title: Comparing "hui," "neng," "keyi"
pattern: 会 vs. 能 vs. 可以

blocks.html: The three modal verbs 会 (huì), 能 (néng), and 可以 (kěyǐ) are all often translated as "can" in English. Sometimes they are explained as: 会 means "know how to," 能 means "to be able to," and 可以 means "to have permission to." This is a useful way of thinking about them, but in reality their usage does overlap somewhat.
The words 会, 能, and 可以 actually overlap a little in meaning. The first step is to understand their basic meanings, though:

• 会 can mean "know how to" and can express an action that you had to learn or be trained in to do.
  • 能 means "to be able to" and expresses having a certain ability or having obtained a certain minimum requirement.
  • 可以 means "may" or "to be allowed to" and expresses having another person's permission.
As for overlap, this graphic helps explain nicely:
The regions marked by letters are explained in the sections below:

• A: ability in the sense of “know how to” (会 is more common than 能)
  • B: permission/request (use 能 or 可以)
  • C: possibility (use 能 or 可以)
  • D: permission not granted (use 不可以)
  • E: impossibility (use 不能)
Both 会 and 能  can be used to express ability in something.

children.english: We all know how to swim.
He doesn't know how to fix computers.

children.speaker: A
children.english: Can you speak Chinese?

children.speaker: B
children.english: Sorry, I can only speak a little.

children.speaker: A
children.english: Are you able to eat three bowls of rice?

children.speaker: B
children.english: I can't.

blocks.html: 可以 is used to ask for or give permission. However, 能 can also be used to replace 可以 interchangeably.
Note: When a question is asked using 能 or 可以 it can be answered with 不能 or 不可以, meaning no, and only 可以 meaning yes. Chinese don't really answer with just 能 when it comes to permission.

children.speaker: A
children.english: Teacher, can I leave a little early?

children.speaker: B
children.english: No, you can't.

children.speaker: A
children.english: Can I smoke here?

children.speaker: B
children.english: No, you can't.

blocks.html: 能 and 可以 can also be used to express possibility.

children.english: Is it possible for you to come a little earlier tomorrow?
Is it possible to change the time?

children.speaker: A
children.english: Is it possible for foreigners to attend?

children.speaker: B
children.english: Not possible.

blocks.html: Only 会 can be used to mean something is going to happen. It expresses that something in the future will happen and is often used to express trends or possibilities.

children.english: He's not going to marry you.
Will you be mad at me?
Will I look good if I dress like this?

children.speaker: A
children.english: Is it going to rain today?

children.speaker: B
children.english: I don't think it will.

blocks.html: Using Adverbs to Add Emphasis

By placing 很 (hěn) before 会, it adds emphasis to the level of ability and skill on the action presented. 很会 is commonly used to mean "to be good at" and expresses being very skillful at something, or doing something very well. It can be translated as "really know how to," as in "you really know how to speak Chinese!" Another way to put it is, "You are good at speaking Chinese."

When 很 is placed in front of 能, the meaning takes on a amazed/surprised tone on the action. Although more rarely used, it emphasizes quantity and amount. 很能 is most commonly used with 吃(chī) to eat, and 睡 (shuì) to sleep. It's like the English equivalent of saying you "can really" do something. For example saying that someone "can really sleep" means that they can sleep a lot.
Note: 很可以 is not a phrase, and therefore this pattern does not apply to 可以.
Other degree adverbs like 真 (zhēn), 太 (tài), 这么 (zhème), etc. can also be used in place of 很.

children.english: He's quite a talker.

children.explanation: My mom cooks very well.
children.english: My mother really knows how to cook.

children.explanation: The subject has good speaking skills.
children.english: She's only five but she's a smooth talker.
This girl knows how to dress up really well.

blocks.html: Note that 很能说 means someone talks a lot, 很会说 means they have a way with words, but 很可以说 is just bad Chinese.

children.explanation: The subject can sleep a lot, for many hours.
children.english: He can really sleep.

children.explanation: The subject can eat a lot.
children.english: Wow, you really can eat!

children.explanation: The subject has great knowledge about food and its culture, a true connoisseur.
children.english: Chinese people can really eat.

I studied for two months. I know how to dance now. (It's a learned skill)
My parents agreed. I'm allowed to dance now. (Parents gave their permission)

Both 还是 (háishì) and 或者 (huòzhě) mean "or" and are used to present a choice. However, 还是 is normally used when asking a question, and 或者 is mostly for declarative sentences.
还是 for Providing Choices as a Question
blocks.text: 还是 for Providing Choices as a Question

blocks.html: When asking a question, 还是 can be used to provide choices or options.

blocks.text: Option A + 还是 + Option B ?

children.english: Do you like him or me?
Do you drink tea or coffee?
Are you going out for lunch or ordering take-out?

blocks.html: 或者 for Giving Options as a Statement
blocks.text: 或者 for Giving Options as a Statement

blocks.html: 或者 is used in a statement in which options are presented.

The structure for 或者 and 还是 is the same, but the meaning, as well as the context in which 或者 is needed, is different. 或者 drops the "A or B, PICK ONE" attitude in favor of a more open, "maybe A, perhaps B... (or maybe both or neither?)" So it's less exclusive and less demanding of a choice RIGHT NOW.

children.english: This weekend, I want to stay home and read or watch movies.
You can take Line 1 or Line 2 to People's Square.
We can contact each other by phone or email.

blocks.html: 还是 for Questions That Are Embedded in Sentences
blocks.text: 还是 for Questions That Are Embedded in Sentences

blocks.html: Deciding whether or not to use 还是 becomes difficult with sentences that contain statements like "I don’t know," "I want to know," "I’m not sure," etc. Alone, these statements are not technically questions. However, when used in a sentence that contains choices, these statements imply that a question must be answered. Therefore, you must use 还是.

children.english: I don't know if this book is his or mine.
I want to know if they support or oppose.
The boss isn't sure if he's going on a business trip this weekend or next weekend.

children.explanation: Since it is a question, it should use 还是
children.english: Shall we take a taxi or take the metro?

children.explanation: Since it is a statement, it should use 或者
children.english: Either tomorrow or the day after is fine.

children.explanation: It's an embedded question, so it should use 还是
children.english: I'd like to know if that person is male or female.

When referring to other people, we can use both the words 人家  (rénjia) and 别人 (biérén). But 人家 has additional grammatical uses which we will explore in this article.
人家 and 别人 both refer to others besides the speaker and the listener. However, 人家 is more colloquial.
人家 and 别人 are interchangeable in these sentences below.

children.english: I don't care about what other people say.
How could I know what other people are thinking?
That's other people's business. Why get involved?

blocks.html: Additional Uses of 人家
For these additional uses of 人家, it would be incorrect to use 别人.
人家 can be used to refer to yourself, and it is often used this way by women, giving it a sort of girly, shy, tender feeling.

children.english: Because I like you!
You are so annoying! You're always making fun of me.

blocks.html: 人家 can also refer to someone previously referred to (in the context of the conversation or body of text) or it can refer to a certain someone that both the speaker and listener know.

children.english: Apologize to them now.
Look how smart he is!

blocks.html: 人家 can also refer to households. In this case, it's pronounced as "rénjiā" rather than "rénjia." This use is going to be the least common in everyday spoken Chinese.

children.english: How many households are here in this neighborhood?
There are only ten households left in this village.

When describing spatial relationships, the words 之间 (zhījiān) and 中间 (zhōngjiān) will come in handy to express the concepts of "between" and "among." Both have a few particular uses, though.
之间 and 中间 can both refer to a space "in the middle" between two points, as long as we're talking about physical space.

blocks.text: A + 和 + B + 之间／中间

children.english: Shanghai is between Jiangsu Province and Zhejiang Province.
Our bathroom is between the bedroom and the living room.

blocks.html: Grammatically, both 之间 and 中间 are nouns (location nouns, to be precise). One difference between the two, however, is that 中间 can be used all by itself, but 之间 is always used together with other words.

children.english: I have two exams tomorrow morning. There is a 20 minute break in between.

blocks.html: Usages of 中间
中间 as "In the Middle of"
blocks.text: 中间 as "In the Middle of"

blocks.html: 中间 can be used for describing location within an object. This "within" could be "inside" a space, like inside a house, in the middle (center) of a table, or in the middle of the screen. You can't use 之间 in this way.

children.english: There is a sofa in the middle of the living room.
My seat is in the middle of Row 7.
Put the flowers in the middle of the table.
There are many people in the middle of the lobby.

blocks.html: 中间 as "Among"
中间 is used when referring to one (or more) "among many."

children.english: Can anyone among you sing?
Among these people, I only know one person.

blocks.html: 之间 can't be used to mean "among" like this.
Usages of 之间
之间 as "Ranging from... to..."
This usage refers to examples like "between 8am and 3pm" or "between 20 and 30".

children.english: You can come between 8am and 10am tomorrow.
People aged 45 to 60 years old are susceptible to this disease.

blocks.html: 之间 for Describing Relationships

The idea is that the relationship is "between" two or more people, with the abstract "between" part indicated by 之间. This usage of 之间 can also refer to relationships between two (or more) companies, countries, etc., but mostly it's used between people. 中间 can't be used in this way.

children.english: There should be plenty of communication between husband and wife.
What exactly happened between the two of you?
She doesn't really understand how to handle the relationships between superiors and subordinates.

blocks.html: Both 离 (lí) and 从 (cóng) can be translated into English as "from." In Chinese, however, their meanings are different. 从 is used in cases where the subject's position relative to a fixed location changes. 离 expresses a "static" distance, or a distance that is unchanging. Both can be used in defining distance or time, however 从 has more meanings than 离.

blocks.text: 从 + Time / Event + 开始 / 起

children.english: Starting from next month, the company will be busier and busier.
I have really liked drawing since starting elementary school.

blocks.html: 从那以后 means "ever since then," while 从今以后 means "from now on."

children.english: Ever since then, we haven't been in touch.
I don't need to work late from now on.

blocks.html: 从 as "From" (a Place, Somebody, or Something)
blocks.text: 从 as "From" (a Place, Somebody, or Something)

children.english: Did you take one hundred RMB from my purse?
I learned a lot from him.
From this incident, we can see your attitude toward work.

blocks.text: Place 1 + 离 + Place 2 + 远 / 近

children.english: How far is your home from your company?
My home is far from my office.

blocks.html: 离 as "From" (a Time or Event)
If you want to say "from now," try this pattern:

blocks.text: 离 + Future Event + 还有 + Duration

children.english: It's been about 10 years since we met last time.
We still have two weeks until our wedding.
I am a few months away from graduation.

blocks.html: Colloquial Saying 离⋯⋯还远呢
离⋯⋯还远呢 expresses that something is very far off in terms of time.

children.english: We've just started our relationship. It's too soon to talk about marriage.

When talking about when something happens, 以后 (yǐhòu) and 的时候 (de shíhou) are often used. They can both be translated as the English word "when," but their usage in Chinese must be kept straight.
以后 and 的时候 both appear in the same place in the sentence: after the verb.
The difference comes in what they actually mean.

以后 technically means after, so it is used after the action is completed. This can be seen as a way of saying "When you are done (verb)ing." This might seem obvious, but in the following sentences, we could use "when" in English for every single one.

children.english: Give me a call after you get off the plane.
Only when I got to China did I realize how tasty Chinese food is.
I plan to find a job in Shanghai after I graduate.
Do you want to keep working after you get married?

blocks.html:
• 下 飞机 以后 给 我 打电话 。 Xià fēijī yǐhòu gěi wǒ dǎ diànhuàGive me a call after you get off the plane.

  • 毕业 以后 我 打算 去 上海 工作 。Bìyè yǐhòu wǒ dǎsuàn qù Shànghǎi gōngzuò. I plan to find a job in Shanghai after I graduate.
  • 结婚 以后 你 想 继续 工作 吗 ？Jiéhūn yǐhòu nǐ xiǎng jìxù gōngzuò ma?Do you want to keep working after you get married?
Use 的时候 for "During" or "While"

的时候 means "when" in the sense of during an action. For example, "when you play ball" can be seen as "when you are playing ball." It is this sort of difference that can make 以后 and 的时候 slightly confusing at times.

children.english: It's easy to get fat if you eat while you watch TV.
Don't chat online when you're at work.
What can you do when you're bored?

blocks.html: 的时候 is also similar to using the 一边 structure. However, 一边 uses two conscious actions that you do, whereas "的时候" can be used for "mindless" activities (like watching TV) or unexpected situations.

There are instances where both 以后 and 的时候 could work and still mean the same thing. These are times when there isn't really a duration, it just happens in an instant. For example, "when you see her." This means, "as soon as you see her," as there is only one point where you first see a person. In this case, you can use either one.

children.english: When it stops raining, we'll go play in the park.
When it stops raining, we'll go play in the park.
Come to find me when the shop is closed.
Come to find me when the shop is closed.
